summary: It is the first year of Germany's occupation of France. Allied officer Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) assembles a team of Jewish soldiers to commit violent acts of retribution against the Nazis, including the taking of their scalps. He and his men join forces with Bridget von Hammersmark, a German actress and undercover agent, to bring down the leaders of the Third Reich. Their fates converge with theater owner Shosanna Dreyfus, who seeks to avenge the Nazis' execution of her family.

Tarantino is a cinematic wizard who proves that he still has plenty left to give, even after all these years.

It's movies like these that make Tarantino one of my all time favorite directors, along with Kubrick, Miyazaki, Scorsese etc. Inglourious Basterds is not only one of the best war films i've seen, but probably one of the funniest ones as well. I loved the ficitional World War 2 setting, which drew from the real events yet went completely over the top with some creative liberties. Tarantino has an uncanny ability to create unnaturally good and engaging dialogue, and combining that with the amazing pacing, you are left with some carzy, action and tension packed 153 minutes of pure goodness. Every single actor and actress in this one does a fantastic job, from Brad Pitt to Diane Kruger to the smaller roles, but my personal all-time favorite has to be Christoph Waltz's menacing, calculating, low-key, ruthless portrayal of Hans Landa. Undoubtedly, one of the scariest, most brilliant performances I've seen on film. And all it takes to realize the subtlety and brillaince of his performance is the opening scene at the French countryside. The small movements on his face, the fluctuations in his voice and mannerisms etc. The cinematography is gorgeous, and the editing and sound design only help the film. There is so much violence (in a typical Tarantino fashion) in this one that it becomes mindless fun up until the very end. Obviously, the final act of this film is a masterpiece, and some of my favorite scenes from the film (which live rent free in my head) come from this one (the Italian scene in the cinema venue). Plus, if you ever wanted to see a couple hundred of Nazis get absolutely decimated in a movie theater covered in flames and ready to blow up, this movie is for you. I strongly reccomend this one, if you can stomach the gratuitous violence, it is an absolute blast and a joy for cinephiles.

In Nazi-occupied France during World War II, a plan to assassinate Nazi leaders by a group of Jewish U.S. soldiers coincides with a theatre owner's vengeful plans for the same. Directors: Quentin Tarantino, Eli Roth (uncredited). What a great flick. Quentin Tarantino returns with the story of the Basterds, a group of Jewish soldiers performing guerilla warfare and terror tactics behind enemy lines to strike fear into the hearts of German soldiers during World War II. Inglorious Basterds is a very difficult film to pigeonhole. It's part Jewish revenge fantasy, part gung ho war film, part knowing parody of patriotic flag wavers and 100% Tarantino. Tarantino has found his new muse in Melanie Laurent. She was fabulous. The performance of Christoph Waltz, playing the Nazi Gestapo figure Col. Hans Landa, is the highlight of the film. His ability to convey courtliness and sympathy and then go to commit the cruelest of horrors is simply superb. Inglorious Basterds is naughty, apocalyptic fun -- Tarantino's version of a war movie, with history rewritten to avenge the guilty in ways that satisfy his pop-art cinema. Like a bat to the head, it's not too subtle, but you can't help but watch.

As soon as the following "chapter" started, it was clear that the rest of the film would fall short of its promising start. You have to start to wonder if two different production teams were working on the same film as it alternates between being painfully dull and ridiculously Hollywood. Only a later sequence involving German soldiers and undercover English operatives comes close to reaching the initial level, and even that is significantly marred by a very brief flashback with excessive electric guitar playing.

Quentin Tarantino knows how to make a great movie-movie. He's emphatically proven this over and over--'Pulp Fiction,' 'Reservoir Dogs,' the 'Kill Bill' films, his half of 'Grindhouse.' He's a filmmaker who delights in delivering layered, circular dialogue, shocking graphic violence (sometimes for laughs), and memorable characters and performances. With this bizarre and bold new film, he has delivered a World War II film unlike any we've ever seen before. It's a deliberate, history-altering picture. Long, tense scenes play like subtle Nazi interrogations. These scenes may seem to wander on but the suspense they generate, the jolting payoffs are satisfying in the extreme. Brad Pitt is a drawling hoot and gets the chance to chew up some scenery as the leader of the "bastards." There is solid support from the likes of Diane Kruger, Melanie Laurent (terrific), and even 'Hostel' director Eli Roth. But Christoph Waltz all but walks off with the film in a deliciously evil performance as a well-mannered but devilish Nazi. Tarantino has fun with history and changing the outcome of the war. He directs with his typical sure-handed competence. This may not be his best film, but it is definitely one of 2009's best and most entertaining movie experiences

Rewriting History for the Big Screen

The 2009 film "Inglourious Basterds", written by Quentin Tarantino provides viewers with an engaging and violent new version of the history of World War II and the death of Adolf Hitler. The film begins in 1941 Nazi-occupied France where we are introduced to the character of Colonel Hans Landa also known as "the Jew hunter" as he interrogates a farmer regarding the presence of hidden Jews. This scene which is propelled by a slow dialogue ends with the finding and then killing of the hidden family with one member, Shosanna, managing to escape. 

At this time, there is also the group known as the Basterds which consist of eight Jewish-American soldiers that are on a mission to kill Nazis behind enemy lines. The leader of this group, Lt. Aldo Raine ensures the scalping of each Nazi the kill which creates fear among German soldiers. The film itself is divided into five chapters which make use of cinematography to give each its own different feel. The obvious antagonist within the story can be seen as Colonel Hans Landa who encapsulates a cold, menacing character with no regard to the suffering he has caused. 

The film makes use of the common good versus evil archetype to create a story full of brutal violence and revenge. After following the stories of many different characters, the audience is left with a resolution to the story where in the end good defeats evil. The film itself contains the obvious external conflict of the war at the center of the story and makes use of surprising character arcs to create more suspense as the film comes to an end. 

Like many other Tarantino films, the audience can expect many dramatic and over-the-top scenes along with the use of comedy regarding serious historical contexts. As we can see from this film, Tarantino also has a tendency to rewrite aspects of history in order to make what he sees best for the context of the film he is creating. By doing so it not only creates an interesting original film, but it can also create some questions regarding Tarantino's authority to do such. The film in its entirety can bring about some form of moral commentary for the audience as far as the ethics of whether or not revenge and violence is acceptable if it is for the greater good. Through his creativity, Tarantino clearly shows the power of cinema within his films which leaves me to give this particular one a 4-star rating.

Inglorious bastards is an ingenious movie presenting the dichotomy between Nazi and Allied power perspective through the usage of incredible cinematography. However, the film over extenuates historical facts regarding WW2, which frequently clouds the social commentary the film intends to convey. Three crucial elements give the film a 3.5/5.

This movie employs excellent cinematography. Specifically, in the scenes in which Nazi officer or Jewish Hunter, Hans Landa, interrogates the Americans, the cinematographers center the camera around not the Americans, but Hans Landa. The importance of this element is played throughout the movie; Hans Landa is seen as a manipulative and toddler-like figure, who finds joy in causing the pain in those whom he hunts. This is especially evident at the beginning of the film, where he realizes that the Jewish refugees hiding under the home are not able to speak English, so he proceeds to speak in French to hide is future intentions. Because he intentionally does this for the sake of killing the Jewish Refugees, he begins his character already as a manipulative individual. With the implementation of cinematography as the one listed above, the movie further portrays the extent to which Hans Landa is manipulative.

Even though the film employs excellent cinematography, the film falters on its social commentary through a historical lens. The film clearly makes it evident that, despite whatever light this group is in, the Nazis are the antagonists: the scene where Hans Landa manipulatively kills the Jewish family and leaves Shosanna alive, the bar scene, and the refusal of the Nazis to have a black projectionist, which all support the western lens of Nazism being awful. However, portraying the historical facts inaccurately, such as the mass shooting of a theater with Hitler caused by the Americans, portrays the Americans in a light that deviates from the existing social commentary that the film tries presenting itself in. For instance, after the film tape switches to the films that Soshanna and the black film projectionist present, the movie theater catches on fire and burns some of the Nazi viewers. In addition to these casualties, Americans are also seen from the balcony shooting down on the Nazis and killing them as they try to exit a blockaded door. By portraying the Americans as the murders in this case, it directs the antagonistic chracter from the Nazis towards the Americans. Doing so ultimately clouded the film's social commentary of Nazi influence, as now the film is showing both Nazis and Americans as the antagonists.

Unfortunately, the film falters again with the main character developments and arc. Hans Landa, for instance, has an inelaborate character arc based on the way he continously stays manipulative and as the antagonist; he continues his onslaught of murdering and has no change in behavior. Likewise, Soshanna, the Jewish refugee that runs away, also develops in a similar fashion where she becomes a theater owner and decides to murder the Nazis within her film theater. While she does have the option of deciding whether or not she should murder these Nazis, she still goes forward with her decision based on her prior experience (Hans Landa murdering her family). While it is a logical decision for the film directors to pursue, this character arc is expected and does not provide nontraditional elements.

Ultimately, factoring in the essential elements in the film, the cinematography uplifts the movie in an excellent manner; however, the movie is hindered by its poor character arc and unrealistic social commentary. As a result of these elements, this movie receives a 3.5/5 rating for Rotten Tomatoes.

Quentin Tarantino's Inglourious Basterds has everything that one has come to expect from a Tarantino film – wildly inventive dialogue, excellent performances, creative direction, bloody violence, and characters motivated by revenge. Set during WW2, Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) leads a troop of Jewish soldiers, known as the Basterds, in pursuit of Nazis who, when caught, are summarily killed and scalped.  Hans Landa (Christoph Waltz) is a charming but ruthless SS officer in pursuit of Jews in occupied France, unaware that he is on a collision course with Raine.  Wildly entertaining and surprisingly suspenseful throughout, much of the tension is derived from, surprisingly enough, the dialogue, where clues are dropped for the audience, giving insight into where things are leading before characters are even aware of their impending dilemma.  The sporadic screen graphics tend to be annoying and unnecessary, but that's a small complaint that doesn't detract from the movie's impact to any great extent.

I watched this movie 12 years after its premiere with eager anticipation, having heard of the greatness of Quentin Tarantino and hoping that he would make a great war movie a la "Saving Private Ryan". I am thoroughly disappointed - it is an absurdly juvenile plot, which overshadows everything else especially because Tarantino did not expend any energy or money into production values (the action revolves around a few tiny sets) so that I did not get a feeling that this was going on in the midst of WW2. But he did spend a lot of money on fake scalps, squibs, blank bullets, flashes, and bangs. (Never let it be said that Tarantino shied away from using 20 bullets when one could have done the job equally well.) And why show us all that scalping in such excruciating detail? Tarantino reminds me of a child killing insects for fun while telling us proudly to watch what he can do - seems a tormented and childish soul to me, especially when combined with the absurd plot. There are some good aspects about the movie - good performances by Christopher Waltz and Melanie Laurent, and a nicely crafted climax in the theater scene. But the ending too was unintentionally hilarious. For me, the best part was that I did not pay good money to see it in a theater  - I watched it as a rerun on the SyFy channel where it should forever remain.

Sin duda lo que hace increíble a Bastardos sin gloria, son sus increíbles manejos tanto de guion como de cámara, donde la misma cuenta una historia mas detallada de los acontecimientos de la historia, dándole una delicadeza increíble. Junto a la increíble banda sonora de la película, la misma se vuelve memorable en pocos minutos. Otro punto fuerte de la película es en como transcurre la historia, ya que me parece que uno de los mejores aciertos de Tarantino en la misma, es en dividir la historia en capítulos. Dándonos en cada uno de los 5 una visión diferente a la de la guerra, mostrando la humanidad que poseen los personajes, tanto en los que se suponen que son los héroes y de igual manera en los antagonistas. Dándole humanidad a cada uno de ellos y no glorificando a un solo bando, como muchas películas de guerra. Que ahí resalta otro gran punto de la película y es en como la misma se burla de la guerra, des glorificándola y mostrando una realidad mas cruda, donde todos los personajes son grises y ninguno carga con el manto de el héroe blanco. y de ahí pasamos a las escenas de acción, donde me parece que tienen en esta película un uso perfecto, usándolas cuando es el momento indicado, ya que cada una aporta un gran peso en la historia y en donde se desenvuelven los personajes, con un manejo perfecto tanto de cámara como de música, donde en unos pocos segundos podemos pasar de una escena que glorifica los personajes a otra en donde los vuelve patéticos, haciéndolos grises. Esta es una película súper recomendable la cual es un deleite tanto visual, como en su banda sonora y en su increíble entrega de los personajes. Sin duda su "Mejor Obra".

Inglourious Basterds - 10/10. Quentin Tarantino's best film is this WW2 revisionist film. With 3 plots in one (following a young Jewish woman who wants to seek revenge against the evil Nazi commander that killed her family, a band of soldiers who kill Nazis, and an actress who is cooperating with the allies in order to feed them information), the movie is expertly written and smartly directed by Quentin. Its one of the few Hollywood films that I know which is almost entirely in another language (only 30% of the film is in english). It shows the authenticity Quentin wanted to put in this fictional war story. The performances are spectacular, in particular, Melanie Laurent, Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz, Michael Fassbender, Eli Roth, Diane Kruger, Daniel Brühl, Til Schweiger, and Mike Myers are all great in their respective roles, no matter how much screen time they get. The film is edited so well too, making it feel a lot more modern with its sleek editing style. It's one of the few films that seems to get better and better every time you revisit it, and its one of the few war films that somehow is able to interject comedy without it being out of place. An excellent film and the best in Quentin's long career!

After a year, and a rewatch, I realized that Ingluorous Basterds manages to achieve incredible things in many aspect of the film; performances, direction, story, cinematography and more.

QT delivers another major, daring adventure into an imagined history that is authentically true, pleasurably vain, and seemingly ultimate all at the same time. No character is to be explicitly rooted for (hence, the "Basterds"), and Nazis can go to hell any day, but Christoph Waltz's Oscar-winning performance as a scheming, selfish Nazi imperial is devilish and deceivingly charming to the point of almost-infatuation. 
Dialogue is correctly on point. Tension never drops. Violence is the past and present, and I think that's what this film depicts in a grand punch. It's gotta be viewed at least once -- if only to see Hitler's hilarious, explosive demise that many still, to do this day, wish a star upon.
A small-scale attack on the Nazis poses a real threat to the Reich's survival.

Tarantino's masterpiece, Basterds is as much of a celebration of the Golden-Age of cinema as it is a fun macabre fable about WW II. Waltz steals the show and astounds as the big bad of the movie. Pitt is also very good, though Aldo is a bit one dimensional, intentionally so. Complex and with a good amount of Jewish rage that's rarely conveyed on screen, Inglorious Basterds is one of the brilliant films of the twenty-first century. It feels personal and intimate and claustrophobic, not an epic, but almost a horror thriller. With some great homages to movies and landmark directors, Tarantino paints his masterpiece while acknowledging those who inspired him. For him, it doesn't get much better than this.

Inglorious Basterds; Tarantino grandeur and glory at its peak

The end credits of the film kick in following the line "I think it just be might masterpiece" by Brad Pitt (I'm sure there's a separate fan following for the end credits as well) and pretty much sums up the magnanimous piece of cinema by the legendary Quentin Tarantino. Tarantino,the undisputed monarch of non linear narratives, goes all guns blazing in his alternate-history depiction of the Nazi brutality and the eventual downfall of Hitler. The film revolves around the bloody and gruesome 'Inglorious Basterds', a group of Jewish Americans vowed to decimate as many Nazi soldiers as possible and act as a harbinger of Jewish liberation. Col. Hans Landa brilliantly portrayed by Christoph Waltz is a narcissistic and callous general in the ranks of the German military in German occupied France region where he's known as the "jew-hunter",is the textbook definition of movie villians and perhaps widely regarded as one of the finest villians ever to have graced the silver screen. With an astounding command over French,German, English and Italian, Christoph Waltz shoulders an aura of hostility and unpredictability and brings in a wave of energy to the character of Landa. He truly deserves the Oscar.

In terms of the writing and characterisation, Tarantino is at his belligerent best with extended scenes of intriguing dialogues, grotesque depictions of violence and an enviable cinematography and music composition. Every second of the narrative gets the audience glued to their screens and appreciate the Tarantino signature style film making. Inglorious Basterds is definitely not for the faint of hearts and those who detest violence in any form.One can't help but notice Tarantino's appetite for violence and storytelling is insatiable.

Amazing movie; classic Tarantino. While the plot isn't believable, it was never meant to be and it doesn't subtract from the captivation the film elicits. Similarly to Django, Inglourious Bastards takes a horrible historical concept and provides a delightfully fresh spin on it. Unique to Bastards, however, is the characters. They act as caricatures of themselves to provide well-timed comedic release and optimal suspense. As always, the brutality of the film generates shock, but the high-stakes storyline justifies it and is only amplified by it.

The acting is incredible, and while it and the plot is overdramatized to absurdity, it works perfectly. The line between Light and Darkness is made abundantly clear in the context of Nazis vs. Allies (pretty much a universally accepted depiction of Good vs. Evil). An easy distinction between heroes and villains and a very satisfying resolution allow for an easy, but extremely interesting viewing of the film.

Inglorious Basterds, written by Quintin Tarentino is a different take on World War II. This war film centers around a group of people who are dedicated to killing, collecting the scalps, and acting violently against any and every Nazi member that they are able to. Tarentino's anti-historical war film shows the capabilities of atrocities when a person is acting under the want or need for revenge and believes that they are on the right side. Unlike other films within this genre Tarentino makes a point to add some comedical elements to his film. Furthermore, he is unapologetically violent in showing all sides and characters of this film. This film shows how violence is justified through causes and beliefs of other people. Something that is deemed inhuman or barbaric is seen as a good thing when it is on the side of the person who is following personal beliefs that are deemed "on the right side of history". Additionally, Tarentino makes a point to include violence as it is used for propaganda. All in all, I would give this film three out of five stars. I find that the messages meant to be conveyed through this film are extremely hard to find and comprehend. Furthermore, the sheer brutality within this film and the ahistorical elements within it are extremely off-putting. This film however was effective through its cinematography and subtle acting elements. The lighting that is used in order to show different scenes and characters aids in portraying the characters in a particular way. Furthermore, the coloration of each scene showing the normalization of violence is striking and the sounds of the violence itself are in the background serve to show exactly the atrocities being committed. Unlike a lot of other films within the light vs. dark archetype both sides commit terrible acts of violence and the film shows the reaction to these. However, in this film one side is "justifiable" in its actions. All in all, Inglorious Basterds is a film that hits on what makes violence justifiable.

While Tarantino's Once Upon A Time In Hollywood (2019) is ineffable, except to adherents of the master or the virtuosos of Cinema, in all it's subtle references and grandiose design, Inglorious Basterds (2009) is a shambolic, thoroughly enthralling piece of pulpy observation on the abrasive nature of violence, and the current state of modern moviemaking. Considered by many a return to form for Tarantino, and others a misfire of ambition, Inglorious Basterds not only offers Oscar winning performances, but strong genre blending thrills in a rather riotous manner and of course, the subtle monologuing no less expected from a Tarantino feature. What makes Inglorious Basterds click is the utter ambition of the director. This easily tops as the most ambitious project from Tarantino, who juggles more plot-lines than he can handle, amounting to what should end as a colossal mess. And while it may not be the most satisfying ending on a storytelling level, the little pleasures spread throughout the film is what makes this conundrum of a film so exiting. And the ending alone is Tarantino speaking directly to his audience in the best way: proud and confident; bordering egotistical. From the famous opening on the farm, on how Tarantino is able to play us like ooze; stretching us as long as he can; but never unsatisfied and totally immersed, to every scene or Col. Hans Landa, Inglorious Basterds really is undesribale. As such, Tarantino makes films like no one else, from his trademark non-linear storytelling to usage of narration and character introductions, this is more-or-less a film where you won’t say it’s his best contribution to the art form, but rather experimental cinema. Obviously gripes include: Overstuffed, too many characters, too short, weird directing choices, etc. Yet despite blemishes all around, it’s never sour. Each aspect of all the faults are handled extremely well. From the second act of the Basterds Killing Nazi’s to some of the backstories of some of the characters, so randomly then not used again other than Pitt’s character. To the baggy structure of the story, this film truly is unlike anything else. While it does showcase an awesome plot about destroying the Third Reich in a theater, and each plot line weaving it’s way unconditionally into the overall narrative, which is a pleasure of itself, it also manages to poke at the use and acceptance of violence as means for accessible entertainment, or rather propaganda. While it does not hold a candle of say, Malick’s Badlands (1973) on a rhetoric of romanticizing killers and the unconditional nature to killing, nor Refn’s expression of the ultra-violent Drive (2011), Inglorious Basterds gets points on poking some on the issue, but not points on a thoughtful statement. What makes Inglorious Basterds work is the sheer ingenuity of the weaving and the attention to entertainment and the smooth directing. It’s a film that is unforgettable; a messy piece of art that many movies would dare not try to replicate. I like to think at the end of it all, the jumbled plotting is a metaphor for modern moviemaking; a colossal mess.

One-Thousand Nazi Scalps- Inglorious Basterds' Success As a Non-Historical WWII Film

Inglorious Basterds is a 2009 film brought to us by the direction of the great Quentin Tarantino. The film follows Lieutenant Aldo Raine and his team of "basterds" on their quest to kill as many Nazis as they can and take down Hitler. Simultaneously, Shoshanna Dreyfus, a French Jew who escaped during the massacre of her own family, plots to kill the high ranking Nazi officers during a screening of one of their propaganda films inside of her own theater. 

One thing about this film is for certain: it is not a World War II historical film. Rather, I believe Inglorious Basterds is a film about the power of cinema. Despite including real historical figures like Adolf Hitler, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Goebbels, Tarantino in no way aims to recount factual historical events. Much of the film is centered around film, with the success of Operation Kino. "Nation's Pride", the film within a film, shows how violence and killing is glorified in warfare. Similarly, the inclusion of Joseph Goebbels in the film shows how powerful cinema can be in the creation of propaganda.

Quentin Tarantino utilizes allegory many times during this film, alluding to other films throughout the movie. I think this usage of allegory helps propel the message about how film has the power to influence us all.

Less than one-third of this film's entire dialogue is in English. This sets the film apart from most other major Hollywood films. Tarantino's use of multiple languages makes us question what is lost in translation, much like the history of WWII. 

Tarantino draws upon elements of the "spaghetti western" genre in this film. The film utilizes many aspects of this film genre which was most popular during the mid-1960s, including tavern style shoot outs. 

The characters in the film are all presented in a rather hyperbolic fashion. The leader of the basterds, Lieutenant Aldo Raine, played by Brad Pitt, has a deep southern accent and screams of American patriotism. Additionally, his band of basterds are mostly Jewish-Americans. "The Bear Jew", played by Eli Roth, infamously kills Nazis by beating them with a baseball bat. 

Tarantino is able to present a sensitive subject matter while incorporating some humor and still avoids glorification of the Nazi era. Inglourious Basterds is a masterpiece. I give it 5 out of 5 stars.

Light Vs. Darkness. (Spoiler Alert)

The archetype of light vs. darkness in the film Inglorious Bastards has many connotations, the first is the obvious good vs. evil scenario that pits the Jews vs. the Nazis. Possibly the largest stain on mankind's humanity, the occupation of France by the Nazi Party and the inhumanities that occurred during the 1940s is highlighted well in the movie. Quintin Terrintino plays the director of an alternative history that gives Jews and supporters the power in a fictional plot that killed Hitler and the German High Command. Obviously, Hitler did not die in a movie theatre and at my point of this writing, I am not sure how I feel about this alternative story-telling. On one hand, it allows Quintin Terrintino to re-write ahistorically and display it in such a way that is entertaining but also gives the powerless power. This is one aspect of Light vs. Darkness.

Secondly, the movie is shot in such a way that it displays the Nazis in a dark way, cinematically. This is partially done by happenstance as the German uniforms during World War II were dark (to blend in with the fog that dominates France and other European countries.) Consequently, the High Command of the Nazi Party is killed in a certain way that situates light entering in the darkness. I feel this is done on purpose to highlight the film's archetype. 

Finally, we see near the end of the movie that Brad Pitt is dress in a white Tuxedo. This is done purposefully to show the Light vs. Darkness archetype that the film perpetuates. We can argue that the film is progressively going from Darkness to Light as the movie progresses. The light being the Bastards and the cinema owner, and the dark being the evil and the Nazi Party.

Tarantino's Inglorious Bastards forces the audience to suspend belief of their preconceived notions of the historical events of WWII. The setting of the movie immediately introduces the viewer to the overarching conflict being told. However, Tarantino splits this main conflict into various storylines and "chapters" all converging together to a resolution that is widely satisfying to a western eye. 
	The brutal violence enacted on the Nazi's by Lt. Aldo Raine's Bastards and Shosanna throughout the movie is largely justified in our minds due to the understood evil nature of Nazi's. Despite this, it is often hard to distinguish any of the characters from representing evil in various forms of violence and malicious motives. Tarantino puts emphasis on Jewish vengeance and revenge in this film, straying away from the outside narrative of Jews as the victim of the story. The violence enacted by Jews in this film is almost unnerving to some Jewish people, who see themselves largely as stepping away from such violent culture of revenge and being the "bigger" person in such a situation. However, this movie revolves much more than just around violence and action. 
	The enjoyment of this movie doesn't come from the violence or resolution, but largely from the creative dialogue and cinematography building underlying tension from scene to scene. The opening scene of the farmer giving up the Jews, and the scene in the basement display this tremendously. Tarantino's close up shots of milk pouring, the stirring of milk, and their accompanying sounds oddly create the feeling of unease in the farmer along with the viewer. This is accompanied by Hans Landa's dialogue, and the ability to talk as if sympathetic, while also being teasingly deadly, turning the screw tighter and tighter. A single 25 minute scene of dialogue might seem unbearable in most situations, but Tarantino is able to weave clever dialogue and allusions made for an incredible scene in the basement meeting with actress Bridget Von Hammersmark. The consistency of the guessing game being played, drunkenness of a new father, and introduction of an unexpected character, continued to pile on the tension throughout the long scene. 
	This tension, dialogue, and violent revenge is complemented with quite a few comedic elements. From Aldo Raine's hillbilly nature, the bastards antics, Landa's giddish behavior, and the Bastards ridiculous attempts at Italian accents. While these elements combine to create a very enjoyable movie, the audience really sees no arc in any of the characters introduced. Every main character maintains the same mindset and end goal. Although Landa does change sides at the end, he has a seemingly underlying motive of simply being notable and doing what is best for himself.
	Many criticisms of the movie come in the eyes of those who believe Tarantino is plundering history and being exuberantly inaccurate, creating a fantasy land of improbable scenarios. However, Tarantino sees this simply as a "what if" scenario. If these characters had existed in these roles, in may not be that unlikely that events could have resembled a similar outcome. In fact, most movies suspend belief, twist history and reality to create enjoyable, impactful films. Tarantino does this incredibly well, with exceptional dialogue, converging storylines, and great acting, especially from Christopher Waltz.

This is a transcript of my movie review you can watch on YouTube by just typing in "Beanlight Reviews."

This review will contain spoilers, but I think if you watched this video before watching the movie, it wouldn't spoil the impact of the film itself. So there's your warning, take it or leave it. 

Inglourious Basterds is the sixth film by Quentin Tarantino, and it's the beginning of a couple of new phases for the renowned director. The first phase is that it features the first star character who is a protagonist that defends others. In Kill Bill and Jackie Brown, both of those women protagonists were in it for self defense, but in Inglorious Basterds, we find Brad Pitt and his crew of Nazi-killing basterds really in it for selfless reasons. 

I mean, how much more selfless can you get but to roam Nazi-occupied France for no other reason but to scalp you some Na-tzies? 

Another phase this kicks off is the reimagining or rewriting of history. Where Quentin Tarantino piles his characters into a period of history and they completely alter life as we know it turned out. 

This movie has one of my favorite opening scenes of all time. Coming into this film, we already know the stakes, we know who's good and who's bad, and these two actors work really well together to build some palm-wetting tension, even before we're shown the Jews hiding underneath the floorboards. 

I fell in love with the acting talent of Christoph Waltz in this movie. I had never seen him before, but even as a Nazi, or the feared Jew Hunter, he had such a charisma and charm about him, that you can't help but simultaneously despise him, but cannot get enough of him. He has so many funny lines, that even after multiple times of seeing this movie, still crack me up, but then he can turn menacing and murderous on a dime. Like, the fire is really pretty until you get too close. 

Brad Pitt, as the leader of the bastards, also brings a unique charm and humor to this movie that I wouldn't expect from him. He's almost slapstick with his line delivery, and I think he's a good match for Waltz. And almost every other character is low-key enough that they help move the story along at a very good pace. 

I can't lie. I'm obsessed with every frame of this movie. I think it's very close to being as good as a movie can get. And let's face it, how much happier can we get watching Nazis get burnt to a crisp and Hitler's ugly face get ripped open by a hail of bullets, eh? 

Yeah, I think I like Tarantino's version of history so much better. 

So where do I rank this with the other Tarantino films I've reviewed? This goes straight to the top of the list as my number one favorite, just above Pulp Fiction and Reservoir Dogs. Of all the movies on this list, this is the one I delight the most in returning to time and time again. What is your favorite Tarantino film based off of this list? And tell me what part of history you'd like to see rewritten. Let me know in the comments below.

I suppose that those who follow Tarantino would naturally like this flick - but frankly, using history to promote gore that makes violence amusing is fare for the audience who likes such stuff. But please let us not call it creative - inspiring or brilliant. As Aldo would say: "It ain't none of those."

Tarantino's obsession and passion over historical events started reaching to the screen from this, indeed glorious project. I'd like to consider this as the writer and director Quentin Tarantino's intermediate state of his creative professional life. This is where his career was in transition period and you can practically see him wire his love for cheap thrills into a much more heavy themes expressed majestically on large scales. His cinema grew bigger with diverse subjects, meticulous world and unique old style techniques. Long theatrical takes that tests both the actor's talent and sparks up the love for old theatre plays among the audience, his conversation aren't funny for the laughs anymore.

This is where I feel he has matured the most as a writer. What was intended to be a distraction is part of a job, now. It is a responsibility. And Tarantino being aware of his influence as a filmmaker and of his work, he loads the guns with poetry and punches with self-explanatory metaphors. The blood flooded on the screen isn't a luxury but a necessary scream that yells out the love. A small kid loving the cinema for what it is.

That innocence is what drew me in, in this latter stage of Tarantino's work, something that I didn't feel in his previous work. His rich characters that he always shines in his film like an emblem is carrying enormous depth and history. And carrying most of that load is Brad Pitt flexing his comedic skills along with Christoph Waltz whose mixture of fear and power conjures you on the screen like no one in the film. But I lean towards Melanie Laurent's character every time she appears on screen. And I have been wondering for a while, why is it that now. For among these Inglourious Basterds that are pragmatic and resemble a lot to the people we live around, hers is cinematically empathetic and offers a hand for us to hold onto in this cold war.

I remember that this was my second Tarantino film. A few days before, I watched Reservoir Dogs with my brother, introducing me to Tarantino movies, and I was ecstatic that my Dad agreed to take me to Inglourious Basterds since the trailers made it look like a good revenge film. I was surprised that the film went beyond this notion and was simply fantastic overall, leaving me smiling as I left the theater.

Let me just say, the early trailers for this film are deceiving. They make it appear that the premise is simply Brad Pitt and his men killing Nazis in a brutal manner throughout. This is definitely not the case, and actually touches on subjects I never would have imagined. Tarantino shows his knowledge for German cinema throughout as the main character of the B plot - Shoshanna - comes to own a cinema, and the Nazis are dealing with where they should hold the premiere for the new film by Joseph Goebbels - Nation's Pride.

The villain, played by Christoph Waltz, is such an amazing character to watch. At certain points, he exhibits intellect and detective skills near Sherlock Holmes levels, and at other times he makes us laugh with how out of touch he is with certain customs. The first twenty minutes of the film is almost fully dedicated to this Hans Landa, and it proves to be among the best sequences Tarantino has ever written.

I fully believe this film had a better screenplay than Django Unchained, but to me, it makes sense that the academy went with The Hurt Locker for best original screenplay. It makes sense not because The Hurt Locker fully deserved it, but because The Hurt Locker was a film that this country needed in 2009 to shape our perspective on the war being fought over seas.

While Inglourious Basterds is not an accurate depiction of World War II or one of the most important World War II films, it is certainly one of the most fun to watch. It is tense, funny, crowd-pleasing, and at the same time it is a very smart movie with well-developed characters, an intricate plot, meta characteristics, and above all, extremely well-written. This now holds the spot of my 2nd favorite film by Quentin Tarantino, behind Pulp Fiction.

I've never been a Quentin Tarantino acolyte, I don't think Pulp Fiction (1994) is as brilliant as some people do, but I can appreciate why films like this are enjoyed by so many. Waltz's performance is a delight and the writing and direction is ingenious in many moments, managing to capture a humor and a tone that feels shockingly modern. He is more reined in here than in Death Proof (2007) and that allowed me to enjoy the film more because the screenplay did not seem so self obsessed and pretentious in it's execution. The sight of so much talent on screen is of course exciting but they are all put to good use and the visual style of the film was enrapturing. This is definitely a film worth seeing, it is a very pleasing 2 hours and 33 minutes that is gory, violent and funny in equal measure.

Shosanna Dreyfus, Melanie Laurent, manages to escape execution during World War II but she is spotted by SS Colonel Hans Landa, Christoph Waltz, as she runs away from him. A group of Jewish-American soldiers known as the "Basterds" are lead by Lieutenant Aldo Raine, Brad Pitt, exist to execute German soldiers and carve swastikas into their foreheads to prevent them from assuming new identities. An adult Shosanna, now known as Emanuelle Mimieux, catches the eye of a lauded German soldier Frederick Zoller, Daniel Bruhl, who organizes a screening of a propaganda film about himself at the cinema she owns. A German film actress and double agent Bridget von Hammersmark, Diane Kruger, and a British lieutenant, Archie Hicox, Michael Fassbender, make attempts to infiltrate Nazi circles while a conspiracy is organized by Shosanna and her black boyfriend Marcel, Jacky Ido, to murder all of the Nazis present at the screening.

The best part of the film is the dialogue as several humorous and witty exchanges occur that are always punctuated by violence. Landa's interrogation of von Hammersmark in particular was hilarious as her excuses becoming increasingly desperate and the sight of his finger plunging into her leg makes you feel queasy. Nice touches like the fact that German's signal three with their thumbs and not three of their fingers are dropped in and Tarantino seems to have made an effort to explore German culture. All of Landa's monologues are delivered brilliantly by Waltz but what is on the page is already an exploration of the evils of Nazism and the smarts of opportunists. I did find the whole exercise to be a bit self important at times, more on that later, but it's undeniable that the great moments in the film are crowd pleasing.

The visuals are rich as Robert Richardson shoots the film like a 1940s noir film and makes the beautiful blondes appear like Veronica Lake and Carole Landis. I appreciated the drama of the climactic scene as blood flows from the heads of Nazis and drenches the carpet below them and a projection of Laurent's face goes up in flames. 

The one thing that I did not like about the film was the performance of Brad Pitt. I think that he can be a decent dramatic actor in films like Moneyball (2011) and Babel (2006) but here he just seems lost. I suppose he was trying to go for camp but it didn't feel joyous like seeing Anjelica Huston in The Witches (1990) it just felt out of step with the rest of the film. Waltz and most of the rest of the cast are giving gloriously over the top performances but their seems to be more going on in their performances than just putting on a funny accent and walking like John Wayne. Every time he appeared on screen I was turned off and this performance ruined parts of the film on the whole for me.

I would certainly watch this again if given a few months of reprieve because I assume that there is far more going on in the film than I was able to appreciate, who knows maybe I will even like Pitt's performance.

Inglourious Basterds is a very difficult film to pigeonhole. It's part Jewish revenge fantasy, part gung ho war film, part knowing parody of patriotic flag wavers and 100% Tarantino. Tarantino has found his new muse in Melanie Laurent. She was fabulous . The performance of Christoph Waltz, playing the Nazi Gestapo figure Col. Hans Landa, is the highlight of the film. Inglourious Basterds is naughty, apocalyptic fun -- Tarantino's version of a war movie, with history rewritten to avenge the guilty in ways that satisfy his pop-art cinema. I truly admire movies that are not afraid to be creative with its gore aspect, and Inglourious Basterds is full of the most interesting methods of violence. Besides that, there are two of the strongest elements in the film that really makes it work. One of them is basically the timing of each scene. The pacing is complimented by the writing in the script. The opening sequence itself is possibly one of the most intense moments done in a simple setting, that being in the home of a family on a warm, sunny day. The genuinely intense looks on the actors makes it to where you can understand how they feel, and the actors themselves get into the film so well that it best shines in the character performance of Christopher Waltz, Colonel Hans Landa. This may be one of the greatest characters director Quentin Tarantino has ever brought to screen. A great antagonist must do two things: make you question his motives, and express a great deal of emotions that some of which would come off you as an uncomfortable man to be around. You can feel the tension from Shosanna Dreyfus, who is played by Melanie Laurent, in the strudel scene. To know that Landa may be planning to murder you soon after the memory of what he did to your family years ago is a thought expressed by the actions that Shossana makes. Once he leaves, she breaks down, and it was something you knew was building up throughout the scene. The writing is very strong in the film, and the fact that Tarantino himself wrote the entirescript is a true accomplishment. With the dialogue in the first chapter of the film, you can feel that different tension felt between both of the characters, along with many interactions throughout the film. There are several instances in the film where a scene builds its tone then immediately alters to a more grim feel simply by the motifs of the characters. Where Stiglitz and the Nazi have their guns aimed at each other's crotch is where the unpredictable struck me. While they did aim fire at each other, I never would have guessed nearly everyone in that room would die in the end. That's an extraordinary scene. Unlike Pulp Fiction and some of Tarantino's other past work, somehow I felt a bit uneasy with some of the gore in the film. I consider that an accomplishment as well, however, as it's truly something so different I can't help but admire it. For people who say that the film's inaccurate when it comes to its history, that's the point. The film is supposed to be set during the second World War and show a couple of different alternatives to how the war could have ended. Brad Pitt's character amazed me, this may be one of his best character performances he's ever done, mostly due to the fact that it's very believable. It almost feels as though the film was written and produced during that time period, but the effects and visuals were done today(or a decade ago as I write this). From the opening moments, this movie proves that Tarantino is not just a master of dialogue, but also a master of suspense, but in his very own manner. Of course, the dialogue is the most powerful aspect in this scene, and in another suspenseful scene halfway through, but what Tarantino displays doubles down on the impact of suspense in a way you've never seen before; In the most Tarantino way he never showed before that his fans, like me, know very well!

The idiosyncratic visual style didn't stop dazzling me with its contribution in suspense, because it simply served at every level. There are many questions left unanswered about her character, and that's exactly what makes her character so compelling. Michael Fassbender also delivered a brilliant performance as always, most notably in the famous " German accent" scene that was the only great thing in a boring, monotonous Chapter Four that made me feel, for the first time in a Tarantino movie, that the dialogue scenes overstayed their welcome.

Speaking of dialogue scenes, this movie has some of the most iconic lines in amazing dialogue scenes thanks, in large part, to Christoph Waltz scene-stealer appearance. That being said, if there is only one of Tarantino's trademarks that I felt was missing while watching this movie, it would be the riveting, seemingly empty talk in a long scene Tarantino is famous for. Don't get me wrong, I said more than once that this movie has some of the most iconic lines, and some of the most clever dialogues ever put to film, but, as a Tarantino fan, I felt that something is missing in these dialogue scenes, and I found that it's the long talk that explores the character, and delve deeper in his personality and psyche.

Another issue, and this time I mean a real issue, I've with this movie is its ending, its very ending. While it couldn't be more satisfying to watch, I found defeating Hans Landa by fooling him in such easy way is completely absurd, and totally contradicts with all the antagonist's wits and slyness. Quentin Tarantino's bloody fantasy take on World War II.

Director Quentin Tarantino's war comedy Inglourious Basterds (2009) is lots of fun for his fans of bloody violence, absurd humor, and visceral action. However, Tarantino's dedication to long-take monologues and sudden encounters with SS officers interrogating people are truly suspenseful drama sequences. They are the heart and soul of how tense Inglourious Basterds feels every scene. The stakes are high for these characters. The opening sequence is already legendary.

It's like Tarantino took the suspenseful interrogation from Five Graves to Cairo alongside the war mission thrillers The Guns of Navarone, Where Eagles Dare, and The Dirty Dozen. It also reminded me of Valkyrie. Tarantino's direction is gripping and striking with endlessly beautiful shots from cinematographer Robert Richardson. Sally Menke's editing is so smooth and enthralling as she rarely cuts away from reactions, so Richardson's camera can hold on a suspicious face or nervous interrogation victim. Inglourious Basterds is quite something with Tarantino's ambitious direction.

I should say that Inglourious Basterds is entertaining, especially if you just understand that Tarantino is doing a nonsensical revisionist take on World War II with little to no history. Nothing like the operation in this movie really happened, nor is it trying to be realistic, obviously with the Hitler annihilation ending. I like Tarantino's writing with his usual strange humor and memorable characters for a perilous journey into France.

It is a highly enjoyable, but ridiculously over the top spin of WWII espionage and assassination attempts against Hitler. You get The SS cruelly hunting down the Jewish population within occupied France as well as an American team scalping Nazis within France as retaliation. I think to anyone saying Tarantino was disrespectful to those killed fighting in the war, you have to simply see this as a comedy being ridiculous and Tarantino providing empathy by way of Shosanna's character. Honestly, go into this expecting a neat ride rather than any notions of tasteful violence or historical accuracy.

Tarantino cannot help himself. This film contains all of his notable attributes. From his foot fetish shots of Diane Kruger, terribly exaggerated accents, gory scalping violence, bloody machine gun shootouts, and eccentric flair to his characters. Only Tarantino could have written and directed Inglourious Basterds. I appreciate his craftsmanship and original style every time I revisit this film. His writing is entertaining. I do find his signature style really fascinating as he allows his actors to deliver gripping performances.

The best parts of the film are certainly the acting performances by Christoph Waltz as the heinously delightful Colonel Hans Landa, Brad Pitt as the constantly hilarious Lieutenant Aldo Raine, and Mélanie Laurent as the devastatingly sad Shosanna Dreyfus. The acting from these three actors carry the movie from start to finish. There are several neat cameos like Rod Taylor as Winston Churchill or Léa Seydoux as the French farmer's blonde daughter Charlotte, alongside a strong supporting cast. They really do contrast and play off Waltz, Pitt, and Laurent for the most part. Inglourious Basterds is really an acting demonstration for its main cast.

Brad Pitt's thick Southern accent and determined bloodlust is as enthralling as his hilariously bad Italian accent as Lieutenant Aldo Raine. Eli Roth's furious Sergeant Donny Donowitz is a riot with his brutal beatdowns of Nazis with his baseball bat. Roth is quite funny here as an actor before he would go onto becoming one of the worst directors of all time. You revel in his killing Germans. Til Schweiger's angry Sergeant Hugo Stiglitz feels like the entire wrath of the audience at the hateful Germans. You can tell Schweiger liked pretending to kill Nazis. B. J. Novak is funny as the goofy Little Man, Smithson Utivich with his blunt statements. Gedeon Burkhard is excellent at translating as Corporal Wilhelm Wicki with a nice deadpan sense of humor.

Diane Kruger is breathtaking and charming as the elegant German actress Bridget von Hammersmarck. Michael Fassbender's fastidious film critic Lieutenant Archie Hicox is a pleasure to watch try to speak German and blend in as a spy. August Diehl's shrewd and observant SS officer Dieter Hellstrom is frustrating and scary. You can tell when and how he notices mistakes in the spy plot. Diehl is as good as Waltz here.

Mélanie Laurent is gorgeous as French Jewish cinema owner Shosanna Dreyfus, who seeks vengeance against the vicious Germans who murdered her entire family. I found her extremely empathetic as she's given no agency when in the company of the forceful Germans. You feel all her pain and joy.

I always have a hard time watching Daniel Brühl's creepy, heinously persistent, would-be rapist Nazi Fredrick Zoller. Laurent feels helpless and afraid with an inner frustration and rage that's fascinating. I felt awful for Laurent's Shosanna never getting a say until her fiery revenge. Tarantino cleverly demonstrates German narcissism and arrogance thinking a French girl in occupied France could ever love them. I liked Jacky Ido as Marcel, whom Shosanna truly loves and plot her cinematic inferno with in Inglourious Basterds. Samuel L. Jackson does great narration for the film like Harvey Keitel's voice cameo as the Office of Strategic Services Commander.

Christoph Waltz is terrifying and funny as German Nazi Standartenführer Hans Landa. His eccentric personality, skilled deduction, eloquent verbosity, polyglot abilities, and shrew manner are fearsome. He deftly goes from French, English, German, or Italian with a shocking fluency. You hang onto his every word and cannot wait for characters to get away from his dangerous villain Landa. There's a reason he won an Oscar for his horrifyingly cruel and cunning antagonist. Denis Ménochet is heartbreaking as the quiet French farmer Perrier LaPadite in the iconic opening sequence. Sylvester Groth's narcissist Joseph Goebbels is grotesque like Martin Wuttke's raving dictator Adolf Hitler. Julie Dreyfus is excellent as Francesca Mondino with her black poodle and traitorous coupling with Goebbels.

All in all, Inglourious Basterds is in the running for Tarantino's greatest film. It's not my personal favorite, but I do love it now. I do think most audiences will at least enjoy themselves during this raucous and nerve-wracking journey through war torn France. Give it a try!

This movie is glourious. Unpopular opinion: I think this might be Tarantino's best film.

"Why?" you might ask.

Because it's so damn entertaining! That is why.

It's practically revenge-against-Nazis pornography, and Tarantino is the Greatest of All Time at producing comically violent cinema. It's a sadistic marriage made in heaven, and this film is the honeymoon.

The performances in this movie is simply the best. Christoph Waltz steals the show as Hans "The Jew Hunter" Landa, a Nazi leader-sociopath so charismatic, murderous, competent, narcissistic, and with-the cherry on top-a flair for theatrical indulgence, he must go down as one of the greatest villains of all time. He's one of those evil characters so sublime, one cannot help but root for him out of guilty pleasure.

Brad Pitt's performance is electrifying and hilarious. As he continually snorts cocaine or whatever-the-hell he's perpetually got in his hands, when he commands "One hundred Nat-zee scalps," my heart and smile grow like I'm the Grinch.

I've never heard of Mélanie Laurent going into this. After seeing her play Shosanna for no more than 4 minutes, I'm positively in love with her. (Mademoiselle Laurent, if you're reading this: je t'aime.)

Oh, and the opening scene between Col. Landa, Perrier LaPadite (Denis Ménochet), and the Jewish refugees below their floorboards? One of the greatest, most stunningly intense movie scenes I've ever seen.

Furthermore, Basterds has surprising depth to it thanks to its (plausible) fan theories: The plot, and especially the ending, being a subtle middle-finger to Hollywood and the self-congratulatory, cliché-ridden movie industry itself. Tarantino's script says: Burn it all down! Or, more literally: "I think this just might be my masterpiece."

The rest is just immensely satisfying, comically over-the-top, quintessential Tarantino violence, in the perfect setting, interspersed with impeccable dialogue. There's much in this movie worthy of more thorough analysis than what's out there right now and/or what I am capable of making.

Bottom line: I can think of no other movie that keeps me so purely, indulgent entertained. And is that not the main reason we watch movies?

Film: Inglourious Basterds

Inglourious Basterds catches your attention right from the beginning just from its title and unique spelling, adding a Tarantino touch to make it stand out from other war films. However, this isn't your typical war film, rather a movie that has literally every genre, ranging from drama and sadness from one scene to humor and action to the next. Inglourious Basterds is set in World War 2 in Nazi-occupied France. The movie right away shies from history and creates their own fictional storyline. The film also doesn't take the traditional "one-story" plot, rather it contains several different storylines with the characters coming from different backgrounds but possessing similar goals. The main characters are an American soldier, A Nazi, and a Jewish girl. They all cross roads to meet the same desirable goal at the end, though they get to their destination in different ways. Brad Pitt stars as the soldier, a stereotypical loud-mouth yank who does before he thinks, with Christoph Waltz starring as the Nazi detective, who is very calculative and has a very large eye for detail. Perhaps the most important character is Shoshanna, a Jewish girl who  lives in France with falsified documents after witnessing the massacre of her family. Her hate for the Nazis grow deeper as the years pass by, but she has no choice but to blend in. Tarantino excels in putting all of these vastly complicated and unique characters together to maintain a plot that in a way fits all of their natures, with no main character getting the spotlight for too long. Since the film is well over two hours long, it is divided into five chapters. Each chapter focuses on a specific event or issue, which helps the viewer not get lost in the plot. I enjoyed that English was only one of the languages spoken in the film, with German, French, and even Italian being included into the mix. This seeks the viewer further into the World War two setting. The film starts off quite slow in the beginning, with more dialogue than action, but the aftermath of the 2nd chapter is what truly builds up the tension and makes this film memorable. I also enjoyed that the film didn't really depict anyone as the "good guy", showing how the protagonists were also like the antagonists in an ironic twist. The antagonist also doesn't share the traditional "bad guy" vibe we see from almost every other movie. Inglourious Basterds is like nothing I've ever seen before. It would seem realistic to every film viewer, including myself, that it's impossible to have a movie that has romance, thrills, dialogue, comedy, tragedy, and action packed into a two hour plot, while also breaking away from a traditional storyline and shed new views on the characters each time you watch it. Inglourious Basterds defies all of these odds to become one of Tarantino's masterpieces only next to Pulp Fiction. The film deserves a "fresh" review with a fair rating of 8.5/10. I would have rated it higher if the film's speed wasn't quite slow in the first half, but it succeeds in sending its message to the viewers. It's a film with stars in its cast, but the actors and actresses that nobody's quite familiar with become just as memorable with their astounding performances.

If one man can make me fear him for ordering a glass of milk, he deserves the Oscar trophy to be redesigned after him. cinegeek.de Inglourious Basterds von Quentin Tarantino ist ein grosser und kühner Kriegsfilm, der so einige verärgern wird und andere wohl auch aufschrecken. Vor allem aber liefert er ein ganz anderes Ende des zweiten Weltkrieges. Eines, in dem die Basterds das bekommen, was sie verdienen! Die Lust am Wiederentdecken alter B-Movies (denn so einer ist das Original aus dem Jahr 1978), der Western Soundtrack von Ennio Morricone und die kunstvolle 35mm Fotografie zeigt Tarantinos tiefe Liebe zum Kino! "The Hero", "The Nazi" und "The Girl", drei ikonische, liebevoll entwickelte Charaktere aus der Horde von Kriegern, die hinter den Kampflinien der Nazis operieren. Gespielt von Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz und Melanie Laurent, die verstanden haben, dass ein Tarantino Charakter grösser sein muss als das Leben. Ich würde es so sehen: Ihre Gefühle sind einfach viel grösser als die, die wir aus "normalen" Filmen kennen! In einem frühen Stadium des Krieges, im besetzten Frankreich, tritt der grausame Nazi Col. Hans Landa (Waltz) auf. Er verdächtigt einen Bauern, Juden zu verstecken und behält recht. Aufgestöbert muss die junge Frau Shosanna (Melanie Laurent) sich in den Wald flüchten. Christoph Waltz kreiert hier einen Nazi Charakter, wie ich ihn nie zuvor sah: Teuflisch und hämisch, ironisch und absurd! Der "Hero", das ist Lt. Aldo Raine, gespielt von Brad Pitt. Pitt spielt eine italienische Karikatur, einen Jäger, den es nach 100 Nazi Skalps dürstet. Das "Girl", Shosanna (Laurent) ist eine Sirene mit Kurven und roten Lippen. Sie ist eine schöne Zusammenfassung der Frau in Rot, die uns das Kino der letzten 100 Jahre geliefert hat. Shosanna flirtet mit Frederick Zoller (Daniel Bruhl), einem Nazi Kriegshelden, der nun als Schauspieler für Goebbels arbeitet. So wie jeder Tarantino Film entzieht sich Inglorious Basterds einer Kategorisierung. Ein Kriegsfilm? Vielleicht so etwas in der Richtung. Natürlich ist nichts, was geschieht, möglich und alles nur grandiose Unterhaltung! Nachdem ich Inglorious Basterds zum ersten Mal sah, war ich mir nicht so sicher, ob das nun der beste oder ärgerlichste Film des Jahres war. Jetzt hab ich ihn nochmal gesehen und wusste: Tarantino mag einfach wirken, aber doch ist der Zugang nicht einfach. Inglorious Basterds wächst mit jedem Mal Sehen. Der beste oder schlechteste? Weder noch. Vielleicht der originellste Film des Jahres!

The opening line "Once upon a time... in Nazi-occupied France," sets the scene for Inglourious Basterds, a not-so-ordinary war film that features all of director Quentin Tarantino's bravado: amazing acting, captivating story-telling, a great soundtrack, and, of course, graphic, bloody violence. Fans of Tarantino's previous works will not be disappointed. Brad Pitt stars as Aldo the Apache, leader of the Nazi-hating, revenge-seeking group the Inglourious Basterds. With the help of the notorious Donnie "The Bear Jew" Donowitz (Eli Roth), a man who beats Nazi soldiers with a baseball bat, and other ruthless Ally soldiers, the Basterds' mission is simple-to kill Nazis. Inglourious Basterds unfolds in five chapters, making it easy for the viewer to follow the gripping storyline and keep up with the vital characters in the plot, including a wonderful performance by Christoph Waltz as Colonel Hans Landa.

For those who are not familiar with Quentin Tarantino's work, if you are a fan of gorey, action-packed films, look no further to fill your appetite. Keep in mind that you would not want your children to watch this film. The vulgar language is one thing, but some scenes, such as a man being beaten to death by a bat, will give them nightmares for weeks. Some may frown upon the obscene violence, as they should. I can agree that the violence might be a little too over the top. Despite this, it perfectly captures the gruesome nature of warfare. Overall, Inglourious Basterds provides numerous high-profiled action scenes, with the occasional Tarantino humor mixed within. Some war films might seem to drag on, but Inglourious Basterds is an eye-gripping adventure.

Inglourious Basterds follows many characters all at once and it would be very hard to explain the story, but I'll just say the important characters and their plot in short. At first we follow a French family who're hiding Jews as a nazi inspection comes to, well, inspect their home for Jews. One girl survives, Shosanna, and changes her name and appearance to blend in with the nazi-occupied France. We follow her for a while, but 4 years later, as she is a cinema manager. Then, at the same time we follow the Basterds. A team of Jew Americans who love killing Nazis. And last, but certainly not the least, we follow the enemy, Hitler mostly. It's divided into chapters and each chapters focuses on one of those three stories, but in the end they all get together in an explosive and brutal finale! Now, I have to admit that this is the second Tarantino movie which became a bit tedious to me after about half of the movie (first being Death Proof). I think the reason for that was the fact that there are many long running scenes of just talking and nothing really important happening, for example the tavern scene, which was very intense, but the wait was very tiresome. The acting in the movie is great, no complaints there. Also, speaking of acting, it was a surprise seeing Mike Myers in this movie! I hoped he would have a bit of a larger role, as I love the actor, but I was satisified by just seeing him again on-screen. The characters are very well made, and I especially loved Eli Roth's Donny and Christoph Waltz's Hans. The scene where the Basterds are pretending to be Italians is priceless! The way Hitler was portrayed in this movie is also quite amusing, to say the least. The movie looks wonderful, and has, again, a very well composed soundtrack that fits in with the scenes perfectly! The ending is very satisfying and I loved the cinema massacre (cinemassacre, if you will)! All in all, a very good Tarantino movie which is a bit overly long, but it's worth watching as it has some truly intense scenes, as well as those that are truly hilarious. I would highly recommend checking it out!

The problem with the war movie genre, through my personal observation, is an unfortunate lack of creative and innovative ideas, as most war films share similar themes and story lines. Much like how the genre was rejuvenated by Kubrick's "Full Metal Jacket," however, the genre underwent the treatment of one of the most inventive directors of modern film, Quentin Tarantino, with "Inglorious Basterds." The movie was a classic Tarantino flick, containing many of the characteristics found in "Pulp Fiction" and "Django Unchained." Likewise, it contained many of the same elements that made these films gritty, exciting, and suspenseful. There's no doubt that the violence found in this film was over-the-top. However, it doesn't detract from the film's enjoyment, as it actually adds to edge-of-your seat feeling that is so appealing about Tarantino's unique style. What gives this film, perhaps, an edge over Tarantino's previous films is the suspense which is utterly effective throughout. I've never felt so anxious (in a positive way) when watching a movie. This is partially the result of stellar acting performances from Brad Pitt, Melanie Laurent, and Christoph Waltz. Waltz, in particular, stuck out as an incredible actor, fitting his role perfectly. Pitt's occasional use of comic relief was utilized wonderfully in a film packed with gore, violence, torture, and other serious components. Once again, Tarantino doesn't disappoint. Though the first half seemed a little slow for my liking, the movie was nonetheless one of my favorite Tarantino films, and consequently one of my favorite war films.

I remember that this was my second Tarantino film. Let me just say, the early trailers for this film are deceiving. They make it appear that the premise is simply Brad Pitt and his men killing Nazis in a brutal manner throughout. This is definitely not the case, and actually touches on subjects I never would have imagined. Tarantino shows his knowledge for German cinema throughout as the main character of the B plot - Shoshanna - comes to own a cinema, and the Nazis are dealing with where they should hold the premiere for the new film by Joseph Goebbels - Nation's Pride.

The villain, played by Christoph Waltz, is such an amazing character to watch. At certain points, he exhibits intellect and detective skills near Sherlock Holmes levels, and at other times he makes us laugh with how out of touch he is with certain customs. The first twenty minutes of the film is almost fully dedicated to this Hans Landa, and it proves to be among the best sequences Tarantino has ever written.

It makes sense not because The Hurt Locker fully deserved it, but because The Hurt Locker was a film that this country needed in 2009 to shape our perspective on the war being fought over seas.

Successfully sidestepping the atrocities of WWII, Tarintino's focused direction and carefully orchestrated vision ups the ante with the controversial and stomach turning Inglorious Basters. The almost completely fabricated and twisted yarn is a fanciful comical tale of sweet revenge that's partly historical, partly the product of Tarintino's own fertile, sharp and somewhat morally devoid imagination. 

Triggered by a rather enjoyable and correctly spelt 1978's B-Movie, determined to outdo his previous achievements, Tarintino liberally douses his surprising music cues with mesmerising punchy and rhythmic dialogue. The snappy hybrid with approximately 70% subtitles unsettling shifts in tone and pace, flow of anxiety and gradual swelling of excruciating tension leads to umpteen memorable moments intent on conjuring response.

In keeping with Tarantino's instantly recognisable stylised brand of splatter fare, the otherwise jagged, lengthy and gruesome WWII spaghetti western yarn is broken into five tautly-edited acts. 

Act one opens with "Once upon a time... In Nazi occupied France". In 1941, Colonel Hans Landa AKA "the Jew Hunter" (Christoph Waltz) of the Waffen-SS enters the home and proceeds to interrogate provincial French dairy farmer Perrier LaPadite (Denis Menochet). Under suspicion of giving refuge to a local Jewish Family the charming and seemingly reasonable Landa utilises his multilingual abilities as a homing devise to cunningly extract that the fugitives are hidden under the floorboards. His verbal tiptoeing leads straight into the masochistic carnage of all residents expect for Shoshanna, the famers daughter whom escapes.

Jump to three years later, Half-bread Tennessee hick Lieutenant Aldo Raine aka Aldo the Apache assembles a motley crew of Hebrew-heritage American GI's. Their mission is to accompany him behind enemy-lines to send a message of terror to the German powers through Aldo's personal peculiar sadistic style of torcher including a requirement of 100 scalped Nazi's. The lethal unit known only as a mist reputation by the Nazi's of the Third Reich as "the basterds" take particular pleasure in beating Nazi's to death with a baseball bat and carving the swastika into the forehead of their victims.

Shoshanna, the 1941 massacre soul survivor has assumed the identity of "Emmanuelle Mimieux" and is now the proprietor of a Parisian cinema. Unwittingly sparking the interest of spotlight-hungry sniper-turned-actor Frederick Zoller (Daniel Brühl) Shoshanna is bribed into hosting  the premier of his new uplifting Nazi propaganda film Stolz der Nation (A Nation's Pride), a celebrated retelling of Zoller's battle exploits.

The exclusive premier becomes a ground zero target for both party's murderous plots when all leading Nazi's agree to attend, including Goebbels, Bormann, Goering and even the high strung Fuher himself.

Aldo hatch's a plan to infiltrate the theatre's premier and cut the head of the Third Reich's power bring about the end of war, Whilst Shoshanna plans to exact revenge with the help of her resistance contacts and  projectionist boyfriend Marcel (Jacky Ido) by setting light to her highly flammable film stock and burning her own theatre. However, will the methodical investigations of Colonel Hans foil both plans? 

What differentiates Inglourious Basterds from Tarintino's previous works is its sheer playfulness. Tarantino does digress, as is his wont, but his irritating indulgences are less pandered making way for this thought-provoking concoction to spew its venom.

Tarintino's casting is once again flawless to a fault. The magnificently sculpted script is intensified by sublime performances throughout.  However unusual, alleged villain Austrian-born Christoph Waltz's elegantly seamless language gymnastics and beautifully measured exquisitely sadistic style stealing the light, even Brad Pitt's fun but highly underrated comical moustache twitching, folk-wisdom-spouting and cringe worthy twangy Southern drawl is not match.

The Verdict: The highly publicised and supposedly gratuitous gore to which Tarintino fans have become accustomed is simply not shocking. Perhaps not for the faint of heart the Mexican standoff of talent, story and comedy emanates vindicating its half-mocking and morally reprehensible historical lust for war.

If you're looking for a gruesome, bloody, violent, but darkly humorous and interestingly charming Tarantino epic then, well, I think it's clearly apparent by now that you've found it. Of the many WWII films out there, this one is indeed a bit different. A lot happens but it is not difficult to follow. I found myself excited to see what would happen next more often than I expected, even though the plot was somewhat predictable at times. It was about as entertaining as a crusade against Nazis could be.

Tarantino structured the film well. He successfully avoided some of the more stupid or absurd Nazi stereotypes, or put his own spin on them so that they were more tolerable. I didn't find the fact that the Basterds were Jewish to be an idea as particularly compelling as I initially expected, but it still remained an entertaining irony. The acting was superb and convincing; I never once imagined that anyone's heart wasn't in it. The brutality, the blood, gore and destruction did not disappoint. It was exhilarating, even.

I think this idea of "ingloriousness" is perhaps the most significant aspect of the movie. It does sometimes diminish from the plot's shock factor because you tend to have a good idea about what is going to happen. But the good part of this is that, regardless of predictability, the scenes never fail to satisfy. No matter what, it never seems as though Tarantino is desperately throwing freshly slaughtered carcasses to the wolves. Rather, he has prepared a very lovely dinner for them, in a banquet hall at a five star hotel, consisting of filet mignon cooked medium rare, smothered in wild herbs and spices and topped with a chive butter. The side dishes consist of fresh peppered potato cakes and an ornamented mixture of steamed vegetables including moisturized buttered carrot mash, a puree of celery, and chopped onions to represent soil and broccoli heads to represent trees and shrubs, and ground parsley as grass. As if that's not enough, for dessert there is French Vanilla ice cream topped with chocolate almond syrup, pecans and Kentucky bourbon mixed with cherry coke. Once the wolves are done eating they shake Tarantino's hand and exit the hotel. Upon entering and starting their luxury SUV, rubbing their bellies after the delicious meal and telling some classy jokes, Tarantino, standing in the doorway of the hotel, pulls out a machine gun and blows the wolves' heads off. Subsequently, the vehicle explodes in a barrage of fiery destruction.

Tarantino lights a cigarette and tries to pretend that he doesn't notice the carnage, although everybody knows he's loving it.

"A basterd's work is never done."  You know, of course I understand that violence is a part of war.  It's unavoidable.  As a fan of war movies I believe I have a tolerance for watching violent movies and the images that come with it.  With Inglourious Basterds, the dialog is very clever at times, and the main characters are colorful and intriguing. However, to me, this film really seemed to revel in the violence of violence for itself... not for the sake of war.
