Personally one of my most revered Tarantino movies, "Inglourious Basterds" is another showcase of Quentin's ambitions and devotion to cinema. Much like Pulp Fiction Basterds is told, not like a novel adaptation, but like a novel--though Basterds is not a book adaptation to begin with, just Tarantino and his creative madness. "Inglourious Basterds" is essentially Tarantino's fictitious alternative ending to WWII, told in two different P.O.V's who are both, unknowingly, working towards the same goal, and ultimately doing it in the same fashion--"killing all the eggs in one basket" by burning a cinema down which is home to the gathering of Hitler's Third Reich for a propaganda film "Nation's Pride". I most enjoyed following the exciting, evolving plot of this film in that it was unpredictable and complex--yet still easily followed. Knowing that Tarantino spent a little over a decade writing the script, from scene one you feel the rigorousness and preciseness in the script with every line of dialogue, every plot development, every character action, and so on. Each individual scene is almost as satisfying as, say, a fully gratifying hour-and-a-half feature film, but Basterds has a whole other hour to it's running time. On your first watch (which, I'll tell you, is not going to be your last) that could be a minor negative--an excess of impeccable scenes. Most Tarantino films, on your first viewing, will usually suffer from too much of a good thing, but, visiting the film for the second time, you'll take in every rigorously scripted scene. Christoph Waltz gives, arguably, his most expansive, if not, best performance. There's suspense, humor, deceivability, and playfulness in Waltz's impeccable performance. There's Tarantino's bombastic, subversive style to add to the film's attributes, the satirical violence, the quirkiness, etc. "Inglourious Basterds" blends in with Tarantino's filmography--it's got all the Tarantino stereotypes--yet sticks out from all the others with it's superior artistic value.

Over the many decades, cinema has tried furiously to re-imagine just about every war this world has ever seen. From Vietnam to Iraq, French Revolution to Scotland vs England during the era of William Wallace. Now although some, like Braveheart, are completely historically inaccurate, many strive to be as real to true events as possible, and with a tried and tested formula, Inglourious Basterds could easily have taken the safe route to success. However after the lull, Death Proof, that made just about everyone question his reletivity in cinema, Tarintino decides to create a alternate version of events surrounding the 2nd world war. One in which Germany are winning the war and have managed to occupy France. However working from behind enemy lines are a collective called The Basterds, a Jewish/American guerilla force that pick of the Nazi's one by one, taking their scalps as trophies and really pissing in Hitlers Cornflakes. Ergo Operation Kino, which sets a plot in motion to assassinate Hitler and his band of merry men, once and for all in a screaning of one of Geobils self directed movies. Having the movie stir the history up into new territory turns the events of the early 40's into a fresh and exciting one, yes Tarintino does his job well at grounding events, so as to make the film not buckle under its false situation, but for the most part fictional characters and new and absurd situations arise, that spin how the western world finished the war into complete fictional bombast. The film bolsters quite the cast, Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz, Eli Roth, Michael Fassbender, Diane Kruger, Mike Meyers, Daniel Bruhl and Melanie Laurent. It even throws in some voice over work from Sam Jackson, just before you Tarintino fan boys have your hissy fit. Being his strong suit, aside from scriptwriting, Tarintino's casting ability has never been questionable and here is no different. Brad Pitt is remarkably hilarious as Aldo Raine, leader of the Basterds, he chews the screen within an inch of its life, Michael Fassbender, although with a brief appearance, is magnetic and fully commited to the material, Kruger is excellent as the double agent/actress, even Melanie Laurent and Daniel Bruhl's sequences together are very hypnotic and full of charm. It is however Mr Waltz as Hans Landa, "The Jew Hunter", who steals the show from pretty much beginning to end. About 75% of Basterds is given off in French, German and Italian, here Waltz not only learns the languages, including english, impeccably but the dialect also. He slithers through languages so effortlessly it is a show stomper of a performance. But thats not all, every scene he is in, is captivating, edge of your seat, bat shittingly memorable, that were it not for his inclusion, this film would tumble completely off its frantic tracks. Tarintino went as far as to ensure Waltz's ability prior to even going ahead with filming, with his inclusion actually making the film possible in the first place, as Tarintino said himself, he would not have filmed it were it not for Waltz being perfect in the role, a choice the director nailed perfectly. Even almost 10 years on, I cannot think of a single thespian out there who could deliver what Waltz does on screen here, he is the ships engine and with Quentin captain of the ship, its one fast paced journey, you dont really want to miss. The writing is wonderful, for the first time ever Tarintino outdoes himself by making every language feel proper and authentic, he even goes as far as to strip back his usual dialogue staples. The script is whitty and full of language, gorgeous and effective dialogue that really allow for even the lesser actors, like Eli Roth, to come across as seemless. Ive already went into a bit about his new world but he crafts it so perfectly it doesnt even stick or rub against you. It was also noted that The man himself filmed this in very quick succession, however watching through, you realise you are watching a very long movie with essentially 5 short stories coming to the same conclusion. In trademark style each one labelled as chapters, this would be a death nail in some other directors hands, however, the relevance and the pacing of all chapters are precise. Each one working of another to create a tense and thrilling experience. Quentin could has easily went overboard, however investing in a more character driven plot, we relate to the crazy characters and the world they envelop. The camera work is gorgeously cinematic and pristine, riffing on everything from war movies in general to spagetti western, Menke also manages to deliver a tight edit that stays true to Tarintino's style, yet offers up something new. One stand out mark for me is actually the use of the wide shot in this movie, it gets used to such a great effect, bridging distance and class between characters, before coming in closer. It allows us to feel detached, just enough to want to jump in more, it draws your eyes into the frame, making you ache for a close up. Very few directors pull the off but mix that with some outstanding tracking shots, jib shots, focus pulls and stripped back camera set ups, the film just feels tightly packaged. Like the director knew exactly every single shot he wanted and needed and i get the feeling, very few if not any camera angles were left out. I also cant talk about a Tarintino film without mentioning the soundtrack and here, all but one song, by Bowie annoyingly, are perfect for setting the tone and theme. Dont get me wrong, i love Bowie but its inclusion brings us straight out of an otherwise compelling partnership. All its amazement aside the film does have some rigorous flaws that stop it from being a wild, off kilter master piece. One flaw i found was the films lack of time to invest in a lot of the background players, mainly speaking, if you are not Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz or Melanie Laurent, your motives and story become slightly translucent. For example Michael Fassbender, although tremendous in the movie, only really gets just enough exposition to warrant his appearance in the film. I wanted to know more about him, emotionally and historically but he just kind of glides in and blows back out again. The film even goes as far to introduce characters such as The Bear Jew and Hugo Stigletz only to hype them up to ultimately feel disposable. Its a minor flaw but Tarintino has managed in the past with bigger and more impressive casts, so with something so small and honed in, its hard to see why it wasnt possible here. More proof of this would be Denis Menochet, who plays Pierrer Lapodite, this man actually gets equally the same amount of screentime as Fassbender, yet Tarintino finds it more important to flew his character out a lot more that someone who is integral to the plot. That being said, the opening chapter is without a doubt the best thing about the entire movie and considering it sets the pace for the entire thing, i can see why he might have wanted to spend a meticulous amount of time on it. My biggest gripe is the movies way of pulling you out of its world, if its not Bowie singing 30 years before his time, its Sam Jackson, sorry Sam. Shoehorned in are pointless voice overs from Sam that stick out hilariously, where a simple flashback or exposition could have been given, its almost like Sam is pausing the movie and explaining the movies exclamation marks. Although it just about works for the introduction of Hugo it completely alienates the viewer as an idiot when later on used to explain how film back in the 1940's was extremely flammable. I cant quite work out why these moments are in here, it almost seems like fan service and not in a good way. On the whole Basterds is the best thing Tarintino has served up to this very day since Jackie Brown and I hate to say it, may have been his last. Not that Django or The Hateful Eight are or will be trainwrecks, however this feels like one of the characters final lines in the movie "This may well be my masterpiece" with just the right hint of doubt and confidence, summing up his career.

Lately I have been trying to more coherently form my thoughts on why I didn't care for "Inglorious Basterds". Now that I think about it some more, it was a matter of inconsistency of tone and pointless violence.

With "Inglorious Basterds", Tarentino didn't seem to know exactly what kind of movie he was making and he switched back and forth between styles with no rhyme or reason. I know people say that's his "style", but he has proven he can work within his "style" and still make a movie that works within its own universe if nowhere else. Here he jumped so randomly between Parisian/subtitled art house movie to exploitation flick to war drama with such quickness that the story lost all sense of flow and I was constantly being knocked out of the movie like a car crash. I have seen these three styles worked together before and to do it well you have to flow one into the other as a consequence of the story and not a jump cut that seem to exist only as a result of the director's inability to blend them together.

As far as the violence goes I really don't mind gory, even gratuitous violence, as long as it serves the story and doesn't merely exist as a gag. For instance the difference between the Hitler skull destruction scene near the end when compared to a similar death in "Glory". In "Glory" a commander's head popped like a ripe zit during a close up and splattered everyone around him in dripping bits of brain matter and hair. Over, done, quick and pointed. It made its impact and moved on. In "Inglorious Basterds" the violence is such a distinct entity in the exploitation sections of the movie that it felt like Tarentino was sitting around with some buddies saying, "hey you know what'd be so super gross?!" and then he built a movie around it. It never felt like it served a plot or a direction for the story. Even "Hobo With A Shotgun" seemed to have a reason for most of the gratuitous violence it showed and there was a consistent tone to the film. That movie was messed up beyond all reason, but the film makers kept us firmly rooted in a world that made sense, at least to itself and it obeyed its own rules.

If this had been a clips movie of short films and it were edited into distinct sections where one third was the straight narrative of the girl, one third was gory exploitation, and one third was the ending where they come together, all presented one right after the other instead of interspersed within one another I might have found a middle ground with the movie. As it was I just didn't enjoy it. Editing it differently may have provided us with a far better movie.

Quentin Tarantino is and has been for many years my favourite director. With the exception of 'Kill Bill', I don't think the guy has made a movie below the standard of "really good", and the boldly titled 'Inglourious Basterds' is no exception. It's got everything you would expect: brutal violence, amazing dialogue, excellent performances, gorgeous cinematography, an infectious soundtrack and that unique Tarantino flare that I can honestly say is totally unique to his movies. There's something about the way he stages a scene, uses character traits and slowly reveals information that is so tense and riveting; and this is particularly seen in the opening of the movie - one of the best in recent memory. It's not perfect, though. Some scenes in the first half drag a little and the running time could definitely have been trimmed down, but the finale makes it all worthwhile, with a highly satisfying ending. It's not his best movie or anything, and it isn't going to have the replay value of something like 'Pulp Fiction', but one thing's for sure - it's damn entertaining.

You know you've seen a good film when it's two and a half hours long and it feels like no time has gone by at all. Inglorious Basterds is an expectedly strange offering by Quentin Tarantino, but it sure is awesome.

However, after all was said and done I couldn't help but feel not much had happened in the two and a half hour timeframe. These people plan to do one thing and then plan to do another thing and then they do it. Another viewing cut short.  To say I dislike this movie isn't a sufficient description; I fundamentally disapprove of it.  Its primary purpose is for Quentin Tarantino to construct all the elements that could make a really solid movie and cover it with garbage, shaving cream, and cool whip.  It is an affront to the very notion of storytelling, which is timeless, unlike Quentin Tarantino's talent as a director.  

There are two movies operating concurrently here.   One is a tale of anger and trauma, fundamentally rooted in the timeless qualities of storytelling, based around Melanie Laurent's jewish survivor, and the playfully sadistic Nazi officer played by Christolph Waltz (the one piece of acclaim this movie justifiably received).  Tarantino proceeds to mash this up with a nonsensical plot involving a squad of Jewish GI's led by a Southern Officer, pantomimed by Brad Pitt in full-on dumbface, a performance fitting the villain of a Three Stooges episode.  The fundamental problem is not that the violence is intentionally exploitative and sleazy, although it is.  The problem is that Tarantino has put together pieces which could be a part of a strong narrative, with numerous fine qualities, and then peed all over it while laughing hysterically.  There are many here among us that think that life is but a joke.  But this isn't Monty Python, its closer to an attempt at Dada by a 13-year old Tarantino fan, and thats the point.  Tarantino is happily stuck in infantile regression.  He has become no better than a hack imitator of himself.   

The critical establishment once hailed Tarantino as the future of American Cinema, but he has instead become the inspiration and driving force of much of its self-conscious descent into grime and stupidity.  Can we just take Quentin Tarantino, Eli Roth, Robert Rodriguez and all their ilk and put them in a zoo?

Inglourious Basterds was a very unpredictable movie at more than a few times. I really appreciated the fact that I almost never knew what was going to happen next and kept me guessing. I'm no expert, but even I can see that director Quentin Tarantino has a movie-making style all his own. Carefully composed visuals, snappy and witty dialogue, unexpected musical choices, and unconventional editing and effects are all hallmarks of Tarantino's works. And, of course, extreme violence.

Inglourious Basterds is no exception. A revenge fantasy set during World War II, this film features an excellent cast playing characters who are rarely what they seem. A young Jewish woman on the run in occupied Paris; a redneck American undercover officer leading a squad of Nazi-scalping thugs; a suave, multi-lingual SS officer who is as sharp as Sherlock Holmes. Brad Pitt and Christoph Waltz turn in astounding performances as the redneck and the SS officer, respectively.

There is the trademark brutality, but it's the dialogue scenes that are memorable. Verbal jousting between characters who are trying to hide things from each other, but most likely already know each other's secrets. Absolutely mesmerizing.

Inglorious Basterds, a film about Nazi's, violence and Jewish
vengeance, what is not to love about it. With it's long Dramatic scenes
to it's more sadistic scenes Inglorious Basterds manages to make a film
that it just simply fun to watch and also kind of a bit insane. From
the mind of a man who has made some of the best violent films of all
time, you have to expect a little blood and you get it too, I
personally felt that the film was firmly very good, and here is why I
think so below.

The story is fun and energetic and although it starts of in a darker
tone than most of the film goes in, it still manages to pack fun and
action that is half humorous half absurd. I especially enjoyed that the
film doesn't take itself too seriously as a history piece and as is
seen in the final scenes, they have never read a history book but it
works and you feel you have thoroughly entertained as well. Finally the
plot also works well as the characters bring so much diversity to it
with varied performances that just the make the story even better.

The cast do a solid job and although I did feel Brad Pitt at the helm
wasn't anywhere near his best, as a group it goes well anyways. I as I
think many others loved the deliciously evil Christoph Waltz as the
Nazi officer who is a weirdly kind of nice person who also can
slaughter everyone he comes into contact with. I did feel actors such
as Michael Fassbender and Til Schweiger Were under used and had a lot
more promise to give the story but it doesn't hurt the music that badly
at all. Lastly on the cast, Melanie Laurent does a great job, and
having seen her mainly in Romance's and straight Drama's, this is a
majorly good turn for her.

Tarantino writing and directing does a job that is rare in film,
producing yet another at the least Very Good film and he isn't finished
yet either. He crafts this sweetly with his fine touches of brilliance
and although this isn't his best, it does a job in itself. Eli Roth
helps Tarantino with the directing and is uncredited so maybe a shout
to him for his help, on another note although the gore may disturb
some, I have to say the prosthetics used are magnificent and
beautifully crafted into some horrible looking wounds, great work from
costume too make this a respectfully good looking film + great
cinematography used also.

The film is very long yes, and by the end is can start to drag also
with some parts where you just want them to leave and move, but in any
case it is fun even for the running time. Sometimes the violence and
gore can seem very unnecessary and as if they could have just the left
that person alone for the sake of not offending the viewers senses, but
yet again it somehow manages to do it well enough to not offend you,
well in my case it didn't but some people will dislike this film with a
vengeance.

I think Tarantino fans will love this as he continues his good work on
and on and with a completely different setting we see him grasp new
situation, so it is fun. Those who also like War setting films should
enjoy as it truly grasps certain elements that other popular WW2 films
have taken, although this isn't really based on any WW2 missions and it
isn't the US army so just a heads up. Those who hate blood etc will
absolutely dislike this so stay away, I don't want to put people off
but I guess you have to be warned before you criticise it. 

Overall a lower 8/10 from me, it was Firmly Very Good and although at first I
was saying it was Great and Excellent, I gradually lowered it as I felt
it is of course very good just not any higher than that. Sit back and
enjoy Tarantino at his best though and although this isn't so much on
par with "Pulp Fiction" or "Kill Bill", it still turns out Very Good
truly showing the talent of this man as both Director and Writer,
here's to another load of years of his work.

"A BASTARD'S WORK IS TO KILL NAZI'S"  

- 'Inglorious Bastards' is a 2009 war film from Quentin Tarantino (Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill). The plot is a fictional story about two different groups trying to assassinate the top of the Nazi Regime. It's title is a reference to the 1978 film 'The Inglorious Bastards'. In his typical way Tarantino mixes long dialogues with sudden brutal action. In my opinion it is not his best work, but I did enjoy it, especially the brilliant performance of Christoph Waltz (Django Unchained) as Hans 'the Jew Hunter' Lanza. Other famous cast members are Brad Pitt (Fight Club), Michael Fassbender (Prometheus), Eli Roth (Hostel), Diane Kruger (Troy) and Mélanie Laurent as Shosanna Dreyfus. 

Four years after her family was killed by SS Colonel Hans Lanza (Waltz) the young Jewish Shosanna Dreyfus (Laurent) changed her name into Emmanuelle Mimieux and runs a cinema in Paris. When she meets German Sniper Frederick Zolter, who starred in a Propaganda film, he falls in love with her and convinced Joseph Goebbels to hold the premiere at her cinema. As the top of the Nazi Regime will be present, Shosanne comes up with a plan to kill them all and avenge her dead family.

In the meantime, the British intelligence has plotted an assassination attempt of their own called 'Operation Kino'. They have send Lieutenant Archi Hicox (Fassbender) to France to meet up with Aldo 'The Apache' Raine (Pitt) and his 8 Jewish-American soldiers who are killing the enemy on hostile grounds. Aldo likes his men to scalp Nazi heads as trophies. His right hand is Donny 'The Jew Bear' Donowitz (Roth) who whacks his victims with a baseball bat. Together Hicox must rendezvous with German actress Bridget von Hammersmark (Kruger), who works as an agent and will help them to get into the cinema.
Whilst it is always a treat to watch Fassbender, Waltz, Pitt and Tarantino on form, is it enough to get past the film's ridiculous conclusion? In my opinion, no it is not.

Tarantino's rewriting of history also contains some of his finest moments as a filmmaker.  The beginning scene with Christoph Waltz and the Frenchman is his best as a director so far.  This is top level entertainment.

Brutal, hilarious and very bold, Inglorious Bastards is Tarantino rewriting history in a thrillingly ballsy way, he seems to be stating to probably mortified historians and even other filmakers, "this is the movies, here i can do what the fuck i want". It's this dark, bold playfulness right down to the song choices ( an 80's David Bowie song in a world war 2 film? genius!) that makes this film so electric and so liberating to watch as a filmgoer. No one has the balls to give us what we want and need as film viewers like Tarantino dose, with his strange patchwork melding of direct film homages and jukebox music from different eras and even other films adding up to something completely new and incendiary, the man is truly a mad magician of film.

Typically Tarrentino, 'Inglorious Basterds' offers a World War Two experience like nothing you've seen before. An interesting all star cast perform superbly to create a tale that's exciting, emotional, humorous...and just about a bit of everything really. An innovative use of chapters, so as to breakdown the films components works superbly. Much like you are told to use chapters whilst writing essays, it appears that films should be dealt with in a similar fashion. The variety of different story lines ensures that the action never becomes boring, and instead gradually leads us to our grand conclusion. The acting throughout is truly admirable, with special mentions inevitably going out to both Waltz and Pitt. As all of our characters descend on the concluding destination, an exciting finale is created. This does not disappoint, and perfectly finalises an truly gripping picture. A willingness to kill off seemingly important characters is an ongoing theme of the film. This brilliantly prevents the storyline from being predictable, and keeps the viewer well and truly on the edge of their seats.

Altering history has never been this good or entertaining.  Undoubtedly one of 2009's best films, and one of Tarantino's best.  Set during World War II, Basterds (purposely spelled like that) follows a group of Jewish citizens leading a rebellion against the Nazis in order to weaken their forces, and an owner of a cinema who escaped death or capture years before the events of the rebellion suffers issues with the Germans as they want her to make a film and show a private screening of the film at her theater, giving her the opportunity to burn the place down and kill the Germans attending.  Quentin Tarantino once again shows off his unique style of filmmaking by adding graphic violence, a long runtime, dark humor, and himself in a small role or cameo.  While Inglorious Basterds does alter the events of World War II, Tarantino redeems the inaccuracies by offering a premise and concept never put to film before (I believe).  The idea of Jews fighting the Germans is hard to imagine, but Tarantino makes it real by offering a smart script, which is aided by his incredible direction, Robert Richardson's cinematography, incredible production values and visual effects, and great acting, especially from Christoph Waltz as SD StandartenfÃ¼hrer Hans Landa, who won his first Oscar for his work (he would later win for Django Unchained, another Tarantino film).  The film's dark humor just make this film oh so funny, especially with its well-crafted dialogue, and multi-layered performances, where most of the laughs come from Brad Pitt as Lieutenant Aldo Raine, the leader of the Basterds.  Something else memorable from this movie is the small but enjoyable Mike Myers cameo, showing us a side of acting he's never used before, and of course is struggling to find work thanks to the Love Guru.  Entertaining, bloody, and full of Tarantino contributions, this is a must-see for anyone who loves Tarantino, or who wants to see WWII play out differently.

When someone labels the best directors to have ever lived, one name should definitely come to mention Quentin Tarantino. Now, I'm not gonna fawn over Tarantino cause he had some really bad films like Kill Bill and Four Rooms.  However, when he's at his best, none can ever match.  When I first watched Basterds, I hated it, mainly cause I was a foolish 12.  Now that I'm 16, I can truly enjoy Basterds.  Seriously, this film was amazing!  I used to think Django Unchained was Tarantino's best 2000 film, but after a recent rewatch , I'm reconsidering.  Both films were good.  Don't get me wrong, but Django is in need of a rewatch.  However, Inglorious Basterds is Tarantino at his best.

Set in the 1940s, this World War 2 epic follows Lt. Aldo Raine as the leader of a ragtag group of soldiers sent to kill any Nazi, along with Hitler himself.  Meanwhile, a Jewish woman, who lost her family to Nazi soldiers, has set a trap.  She poses as the owner of a theater, which will premiere one of the supposedly best films ever.  Of course, Mr. Hitler will be in attendance.  Many plots are interwoven, including one about German soldier Hans Landa, who is much smarter than he appears.  The film has a different premise than his other films, but don't get that wrong.  It still has that Tarantino feel to it, so if you're not a fan of Pulp Fiction, Resevoir Dogs, or Kill Bill, stay away.  However, this a must see for Tarantino fans cause I will tell you this: It's one of his best works to date.

The best thing this film has going for it is Tarantino's script without a doubt.  If you're not a fan of dialogue driven films, you'll leave this film wanting more.  Much of the film is comedic, which can be interpreted wrong at times.  Sometimes the comedy seemed to happen at the wrong time, making it seem as if every German soldier deserved to die.  This is my biggest complaint for the film because it makes it seem as if all German soldiers supported the Nazi regime.  It's inaccurate, and many Germans may feel it's distasteful.  I kind of do, but I can't help but say that it boosts the film.  Of course, this film features Tarantino's style of violence.  Outrageous amounts of blood spill and some deaths are very brutal, namely the introduction to the Bear Jew (played by Eli Roth).  It's violence actually helps the film, however.  It gives it a very realistic feel reminding us that WW2 was a brutal fight.  While doing this, Tarantino also entertains un in his own special way.

Also, I can't review this film without mentioning Christoph Waltz' Hans Landa.  This guy is truly amazing.  Every scene he's in is completely amazing.  His character is one of the best villains ever.  He lifts this film above average territory straight into amazing.  The opening scene in which he haunts down a Jewish family reveals everything about him.  I love a film where I can understand a character based off of one scene.  I understood that Landa was a much smarter soldier, who only cares for his own well being.  He's ruthless and cold.  It truly is amazing.. Tarantino made a really amazing character.  However, I wasn't fond of Pitt's performance in this film.  He was used more as the comic relief, and while it was funny at times, he gets annoying after a while.  I really felt like he really  didn't add anything to the film.

Overall, Inglorious Basterds is a pretty good film.  Definitely one of Tarantino's best written films right now.  It features some intense scenes and some pretty crazy shootouts.  Sure, the violence maybe a little too gratuitous, but it lets be honest here.  Nobody does violence better than Tarantino.  Some would complain about the very distasteful portrayal of all German soldiers because most didn't support the Third Reich.  However, I loved this film, mainly cause of the grand scale of things.  Rather than feel  like a small time robbery like most of Tarantino's films, it feels more epic in it's scope, which really gives a vibe unmatched by his other films.  Of course the film is weighed down by the comedy, which really wasn't bad, but it felt unnecessary in some moments.  However, I believe this was Tarantino's best film since Pulp Fiction.  And I believe Tarantino thinks the same way.  In the end, a character says, "You know.  This might just be my masterpiece."  Is that Tarantino telling us something?  I think so.

Many people regarded Death Proof as a disappointment and they were all hoping that Tarantino will come back to his best form in his next film, though I did think highly of Death Proof, and what a come back he did. Inglourious Basterds is his 6th film and it shows Tarantino going back to the things that made his film great whilst doing something unique.

Inglourious Basterds is written by Quentin Tarantino, and he has rewritten history with this film. In doing that, it does run the line of controversy as people may think of his vision or retelling as ridiculous or pompous. I never saw it that way, because I never gave this film the seriousness that I usually would give to a film like Schindler's List or Saving Private Ryan, instead I came into this looking for some fun and that is definitely what I got. Tarantino here has brought back the non-linear approach to his storytelling. He dedicates the first three chapters of the film as an introduction to the key players of the last chapter, and having the 4th Chapter 'Operation Kino' as the driving plot point. Tarantino has avoided his first three chapters to repeat themselves and telling us what we already know, instead it dedicates each one solely to it's characters and nothing else. It kept me hooked because with each chapter, he adds on more information that we didn't know which builds it all up for the last two chapters of the film. Tarantino has played around with history in this film, which is definitely a first for him, and he would later do this for Django, but not to the degree of change and impact that this film demonstrates. The film shows off entertaining and quirky characters, which hasn't been found in his films since his 90's flicks. Tarantino has given his characters much more depth here than most of his previous films would give, and he continuous it with his next film, and it does allow me to connect with these characters more and understand their inner workings due to their given back-stories. The dialogue in this film is top notch, at times very reminiscent of the style that was used for Pulp Fiction, as it kept me more interested as more words come out from these characters. Tarantino was also able to add in for his characters, the knowledge he has on film of that era which I thought was a nice touch. To some people, they may see it as a return to Tarantino's indulgent style of dialogue but that's what makes his films special in the first place, so the more the better.

Not at all did the film bore me, this is because Tarantino is in love with his own dialogue and he makes it the star of the scene. Tarantino fills the scene with dialogue, as a build up of sorts towards the violent and explosive ending that the scene needs in order to be relieved and pumped for what comes next. As I said before the non-linear storytelling of the film and using the bulk of the film to create and introduce it's characters, it doesn't get boring as it doesn't repeat itself and always give off something new. Some people find a lot of Tarantino's films to have a pacing problem and I can understand where they are coming from, but Inglourious Basterds is one of those films that felt like it moves forwards all the time regardless how still a scene may seem because it keeps throwing interesting things your way and in a lot of scenes, Tarantino was able to convey tension that keeps you on the edge of your seat thinking something might happen. Ultimately, Tarantino is just making a revenge film set in the era of World War 2, and people may complain that it lacks a bit of substance and never asks any questions about morality and doesn't put the Germans, or the Americans for that matter based on the method of their killings, trial for their actions. I don't really think it needed that because, that's not what this film is meant to be, this is supposed to be just a fun revenge flick. Tarantino has used non-English dialogue with subtitles in his previous films, Kill Bill, and now he has put that up front with this film, using it as a style in making this film unique and allowing the film to feel more genuine.

Robert Richardson is back to do another of Tarantino's film and with each film I start to see a connection and understanding of each other's visions. Richardson understands what the film needs to create that homage atmosphere that Tarantino intends his films to look like. Richardson and Tarantino has brought back their trademark shots like long takes and the trunk shot. Because this film is a dialogue driven film, Richardson contains a lot more closeups than his previous films and this does allow us to get in touch with these characters and see the emotional rumblings that they hide behind the facade due to the current situation, especially Melanie Laurent's character. As time gone by, Tarantino's vision has gotten bigger with scripts that are very ambitious and an increase in budget, this allows the characters to be not too confined in a certain space and allowing the film to have multiple and a variation in locations to shoot. The film's photography seems to strip away the over saturation of it's colors, like Kill Bill and Death Proof, and takes a more darker and grimier look for the film.

The film doesn't contain a composer writing an original score, instead it uses soundtracks that are more score driven. The tracks that are chosen are Sergio Leone/Ennio Morricone inspired, which on paper would be an odd choice as it suits more of the Western era but after seeing this film, you hardly even notice it and at the end you realize that it actually works. There are specific moments that are supported by a track that makes the moment seem perfect but Tarantino has the habit of cutting it off and not giving the scene a proper conclusion, which gives off a comedic feel and prevents it from being too melodramatic.

Brad Pitt may be seen as the frontrunner of the film but the film is more of an ensemble piece. The first three chapters are dedicated to a certain character(s), and this allows these actor(s) to shine in their segments. Brad Pitt definitely brings a surge of energy in this film, working with a character that feels almost specifically written for him. The other standout was Christoph Waltz, playing a character that has a personality that I have haven't seen before. Waltz brings such charm and personality to a character that is regarded by most people as the ultimate Jew killer. The Supporting Actor win at the Oscars for Waltz was definitely deserving. Tarantino has used an international cast before but not as diverse as this film. Inglourious Basterds has made a star and showcased the talents of actors like Melanie Laurent and Daniel Bruhl. Though Michael Fassbender has been on films before this like 300 but this film put him on the map, the bar scene segment was tense and thrilling and a part of it is due to Fassbender's performance.

Inglourious Basterds is a remarkable film and a demonstration of Tarantino's ability to take something that has been used a billion times in films and make it feel fresh and unique. The film boasts wonderful dialogue, amazing sequences, fantastic performances front actors, smart choice of music, and excellent photography. Inglourious Basterds is a rival for the number one spot for my favorite Tarantino films.

I could write an entire essay over how I feel over this subject, but this review is on 'Inglourious Basterds'.  Okay, so I can see where this movie is coming from, in that it aims to fantasize over what might have happened if Hitler got his shit handed to him when he really deserved it.  The movie is an artistical masterpiece, and as usual, the actors deliver very solid performances. I suppose it also didn't help that Bryan Singer's much more sympathetic depiction of the Nazis ('Valkyrie') came out so close to this one.

Inglourious Basterds follows Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) and his group of 'basterds' as they invade Nazi-occupied France with the mission to claim Nazi scalps. The basterds team up with German actress Bridget von Hammersmark (Diane Kruger) when they learn that the Nazis will be attending the French premiere of "The Nation's Pride," a German propaganda film based on the heroic tale of Fredrick Zoller (Daniel Brühl). The Basterds hatch an explosive plan to use the premiere to wipe out as many Nazis as they possibly can; yet with diabolical Col. Hans 'Jew Hunter' Landa (Christoph Waltz) on their case, would the plan go off as expected.

Tarantino yet again does a film the way he wants to, and with Inglourious Basterds he writes his own history. As expected, the script and dialogue is phenomenal, heavy, but extraordinarily good. The characters he writes are incredible to watch on screen, and he yet again casts beautifully. However, what stops Basterds from being up their will Pulp Fiction is that the segments that the film is split into, doesn't quite fit together as sweetly as Pulp Fiction did. This film feels more like a bunch of sequences just placed together rather than one individual film, whereas with Pulp, although split into different stories, the sequences fit together so nicely that it worked brilliantly.

As with all Quentin Tarantino, the actors chosen are sublime with the stand-out performance going to Christoph Waltz. Waltz's Hans Landa takes evil to a new level as he interrogates his victim with such confidence, such calmness, that he provokes fear from his reputation and ruthlessness. Landa's personality oozes charm with a straight shooting malice (in four language) that is just outstanding to watch. Hugely deserving of the Oscar for best supporting actor and the making of this film.

For any die-hard QT fan this film will not disappoint. Will it polarize the audience? Possibly.

Inglourious Basterds is an excellent film, let me say that.  In fact, I'll go so far as to say that it's my favorite Tarantino flick, though not quite as quotable as Pulp Fiction.  The problem, as I'll get into, lies in how the movie was advertised.
Does this movie tell a complete story?  Yes.  It has a definite beginning, definite end, good pacing, and leaves very few questions hanging, which in this movie, is a good thing.  One star.
Are the effects and acting believable?  Not much in the way of super special effects needed for this movie besides blood, explosions, and gunshots, and they're all done perfectly.  The acting is spot-on.  Pitt plays a crazy but sensible Lt. Raine.  Waltz even won an Oscar for his role as Col. Hans Landa.  One star.
Does this movie avoid cliché?  In all the ways that matter, yes.  A few are played on for humor purposes, but it's not anywhere near bad enough to warrant not giving a whole star.  Even if it was, the unarguably un-cliché ending would be enough to cancel it all.  One star.
Does this movie do what it set out to do? Yes, but only to a point.  This movie was advertised in theaters and on TV as being a hardcore gritty WWII action flick.  While the hardcore and gritty (and WWII, thankfully) parts are down-pat, this is not an action movie, and a lot of people may be turned off if they're expecting WWII Die Hard and get something closer to The 39 Steps.  This is a thriller movie, with lots of dialogue, tension, and suspense, and it does that to a "T", but it loses half a star for bad advertising.  1/2 star.
Does this movie have a takeaway?  *SPOILER ALERT* *SPOILER ALERT* Well, yes, but rightfully so.  "How are they building up to all this without finally killing Hitler?" You may ask.  "What's that about not killing Hitler?" Tarantino replies, "I can't hear you over the sound of me killing Hitler."  Tarantino boldly claims that he could have done WWII better than the actual people in charge did, and for that and changing history, it gets one star.
Final score: 4.5 stars.  This is my favorite movie right now and I highly recommend it to anybody who is a fan of a good story.

I wasn't sure what to expect coming into Inglourious Basterds. It was a $5 impulse buy (what a shame), and my only other Tarantino film to date was Pulp Fiction. That one was the hardest R I'd ever seen, so I was a little worried about watching a war movie from the same writer/director. The best way to describe the sensation of watching is that it was like cutting off a bite of perfectly cooked steak and rolling it around in my mouth, savoring the flavor as long as possible.

The idea is that Brad Pitt's Basterds are going to try to end World War II with their Apache guerilla tactics, but the wrinkle is that Christoph Waltz's "Jew hunter" is their nemesis. Tarantino masterfully walks the tightrope of suspense throughout. Coming in, I'd thought this was an action flick (and this certainly has its share of that), but I'd label it more on the side of thriller; the whole thing is a series of will-he-or-won't-he moments, culminating in one of the gutsiest endings I've ever seen (itself a will-Tarantino-or-won't-he situation).

There's not much to dislike about Inglourious Basterds--except for the violence/gore (there's a bit of sex/language, but no more than any other soft R, I think). Between the scalping and the swastika carving on foreheads, this is not a movie for the faint of heart, children, or mothers. I found myself flinching a few times, thinking, "we're supposed to be the good guys!" Basterds, however, transcends that. It's a movie about stereotypes doing things they're not supposed to do: American, German, French, Jew, and Tarantino. I think that...not necessarily excuses, but explains most of what I reacted to.

However, with that caveat of violence made known, I would encourage you to see Inglourious Basterds. The pacing is perfect, the suspense is brilliant, the characters are amazing, the tone is pitch-perfect, and the praise is gushing a little too freely. Just watch the movie already.

"Bastardos Inglórios", do Quentin Tarantino, é um daqueles filmes de ação que te fazem ficar de queixo caído até o final da projeção. Recheado do típico humor "tarantinesco" e de incríveis diálogos espertos, que te faz se surpreender com cada fala recitada, o filme pode ser considerado não apenas como mais uma obra de Tarantino, mas sim como o melhor filme do diretor após "Pulp Fiction - Tempo de Violência". Transformando a Segunda Guerra Mundial em uma deliciosa e super criativa aventura, o que Tarantino faz cruza as fronteiras e os limites estabelecidos por todos os filmes de nazismo até então: para a fértil imaginação deste único diretor, a Segunda Guerra Mundial acabaria dentro de um cinema, com a morte de centenas de nazista (E até mesmo do próprio Hitler!) realizadas pelas mãos de um grupo de judeus americanos e vingativos, liderados pelo Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt, em uma divertidíssima interpretação!), que tem como o objetivo matar oficiais nazistas de forma bárbara, para espalhar o medo e o pavor entre os seguidores do "Fuhrer".
O longa segue uma estrutura estilosa (claro, como não falar de Tarantino sem se referir ao seu estilo único!), que sendo dividida em atos, acabam fazendo com que algumas cenas fiquem um pouco longas (a cena do bar em que acontece o tiroteio, por exemplo, deve ter consumido mais de vinte minutos do filme). Ao contrário do que muitos podem pensar, a grande duração destas cenas não transformam "Bastardos Inglórios" em um filme maçante, mas acabam fazendo com que os momentos de ação causem mais impacto e - também - permitem que o roteiro extremamente bem escrito (considero este o melhor roteiro do diretor deste 'Pulp Fiction') tenha mais tempo para mostrar o seu poder e sua competência.
Tarantino não apenas conseguiu escrever um roteiro perfeito, como também encontrou um ator desconhecido chamado Christoph Waltz (o famoso "Caçador de Judeus"). A sua interpretação, que lhe rendeu o Óscar de Melhor Ator Coadjuvante, é um dos grandes pontos altos do filme! Waltz consegue, com a sua interpretação cordial, educada, sarcástica e assassina, dar vida ao General Hans Landa de uma forma que impressiona, conseguindo o transformar em um personagem ameaçador e assustador.
E o final do filme - um dos grandes momentos de toda a carreira do Tarantino - é algo que te deixa de queixo caído.  Óbvio que pela exagerada violência e pela enorme quantidade de sangue, mas também com a imaginação sem limites que este diretor fabuloso têm. Para mim, um marco na história do cinema!

Writer/director Quentin Tarantino tries his hand at a historical epic in the World War II film Inglourious Basterds.  The film follows two parallel stories, one of an American Special Forces unit that carries out covert attacks, the other of a French Resistance theatre owner, as they converge in an attempt to assassinate the Nazi high command at a film premiere.  Featuring an all-star cast that includes Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz, Melanie Laurent, Michael Fassbender, Eli Roth and Diane Kruger, the performances are exceptionally good.  However, Tarantino's flare for dialog has trouble translating, and gets bogged down in minutia.  The film also has some pacing issues, and the storytelling's a bit weak.  Inglourious Basterds is entertaining and Tarantino delivers some brilliant sequences, but the film as a whole is uneven and lacks focus.

Before I review the movie I should address the topic that Tarantino chose for this one and my thoughts on it. 

It does bother me somewhat using real historical times for bloodthirsty action movies and I was disappointed to see Tarantino go down that route, especially with WWII, it's far from imaginative. There are plenty of Tarantino movies that I love the violence in- near enough all of them because it is over the top popcorn action and it is our fictional hero getting revenge or whatever but when we are talking about Nazis who actually did these things to real people it just leaves me feeling queasy to see it exploited in film. War movies in general do little for me unless they are using the violence to convey the damage that comes from it or something similar and thankfully there's lots of war movies that do just that and the ones that don't generally aren't violent enough to bother me.  However this film is a pretty grim example and it is work like this that reminds me that Tarantino is indeed a prick.

Regardless, a prick can still make good movies and this is one of them but it looses marks from me for the lazy and unashamed use of Nazis for bad guys and Jews for victims. Of course Tarantino turns it around and says "No, we are killing the Nazis, it's revenge, it is totally fine" or something like that but his film shows otherwise- the opening scene after all involves a Jewish family in hiding being shot to death from above by several Nazis. Now, sure, it gives us our bad guy and blah blah, but really as soon as we see a Nazi who takes pride in being called the 'Jew-hunter' he is already fully-established as evil, killing people after that is just getting off and I'm not willing to give Tarantino the benefit of the doubt with this one.

The worst thing though is just how unimaginative it is- I've never found imagination to be what Tarantino does best, he sticks to the same formula throughout his films, there's little themes that you couldn't easily find elsewhere and there's generally just a lot of shooting or whatever. This is fine though because he has other strengths but by using events like WWII he is weakening his strong points by further showing his lack of imagination. Umm, has he done cowboys and Indians yet?

So that's where I lie with the subject matter but actually, despite my disappointment with it, it is only one element of the film and some of the others on show are displays of Tarantino at his best.

Dialogue-wise this is my favourite of his, it's very hit and miss as always but you can feel the care that went into it and some scenes really benefit from it. It's not quirky as in Reservoir Dogs nor as fun as in Pulp Fiction but it's more interesting than with the likes of Kill Bill and Jackie Brown and it adds more to specific scenes than it ever did in his other films. (okay, maybe in Pulp Fiction too.)

The characters were kind of disappointing inn this one- they just didn't capture my attention too much, Raine in particular was just Brad Pitt getting paid to be annoying for me. The story overall has enough of what I expect from Tarantino but it still isn't as strong as his' previous work. 

The real strength in this one is Tarantino's ability to create memorable scenes, ones that hang around in your mind long after you've forgotten most of what happens in the film. There are several great scenes like that in here- the opening scene for example is brilliant. (aside from killing the family- the same impact could have been made had it just been hinted at rather than getting off on showing it)

It's well-written, looks great, has tension, is superbly acted- it really is a brilliant opening scene. Scenes like that are Tarantino's talent and when there's enough of them they make for a great movie- here we have some great moments in an overall below-par show for Tarantino however it still has some of the other touches that make a Tarantino film work (though many of these are old now) and it is by no means a bad film. More importantly, it isn't a movie that should be analysed in the way that I've tried to do, it is simply one that should be watched to pass the time and in that way, this is surely a good film.

This is one of the all time great Tarantino films, and I loved every minute of it. What I loved about this film is how Tarantino was able to apply some of the characteristics of his style from films like Pulp Fiction to a completely different type of film for him. He was able to apply things like really long but interesting talking scenes to this, which were all in several different languages. Most of his films are long but they don't have many scenes. They just have scenes that go on for a long time He also made it seem like there were several different stories, and there were, but they were in order. The film had different chapters like his films like Pulp Fiction, and Kill Bill has. That is how they make it seem like there are multiple story lines. It was a classic Tarantino film for that reason.

Also like all of Quentin Tarantino films the acting is really good. His screenplays are so well written that it allows actors like Brad Pitt, and Christoph Waltz to show their skills as actors. I think that if you are an actor with talent it is hard not to be really good in his films, because of how good his directing, and screenwriting is. Something about the way he works just allows actors to be awesome in his movies. It is part of the reason why Quentin Tarantino is my favorite director. In interviews for his films I find it obvious that actors in his films just love working with him, and love what he does. I feel like true film buffs, and actors will love his films especially. The more and more I have gotten into films the more and more I have grown to love Quentin Tarantino. This is a film that also got better and better for me. First time I saw it I gave it an 8.5/10 and now it is a 10/10. Just an amazing and classic Tarantino film.

However it was a very different one for him, because of the topic. This is the first time that he touched a topic that had importance on the world. All of his films before were just really interesting and well done stylized films. In this film he did a very historically inaccurate version of the holocaust. We all know what happened in the holocaust, but this film in my opinion is the way that a lot of people wish that the holocaust really happened. The idea of a group known as "The Basterds" going around killing Nazi's, and getting revenge on them for starting the holocaust sounds better then a bunch of Nazi's killing millions of Jews in a few years in my opinion. I feel like this is how Tarantino really wished the holocaust happened. I felt like he probably felt like the holocaust could have ended so much quicker if what happened in this film really did happen. They ended the war in a way that seemed so much simpler then the way it really happened. When you think about it was way simpler, and it ended way better in the movie in my opinion. I think certain people may like this movie because of that. I liked it because of that. It kind of gave me a perspective on how the holocaust could have happened, and I liked that perspective that Quentin Tarantino gave me a lot.

I find that he takes everything to the next level with his films. He takes violence, brutality, acting, and dialogue to the next level, but he also takes awesomeness to the next level. He really did that for me with this film. Really the only Tarantino film that didn't blow me away was "Death Proof." That is a really bad Tarantino film, and I felt like he was going through some severe writers block when he did that, but he got his genius back to write "Inglourious Basterds." This was one of his ingenious films for sure. This film really took all aspects of cinema that make movies awesome, and he took it to the next level, and then some. That is the reason why I gave this film a 10/10.

Now what actually happened in this film is that there is a group of Jewish men known as "The Basterds" going around killing Nazi's. It is lead by Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) an American from Tennessee. He gives his men a goal of killing one hundred Nazi's, and to bring back one hundred Nazi scalps. They become known and hated by Nazi's around Germany, and Adolf Hitler (Martin Wuttke). In one scene they kill a bunch of Nazi's but they let one go. They let the one go who told them the information they wanted. However when they let a Nazi live Aldo gives them "Something that they won't be able to take off." What that thing that they won't be able to take off is specifically is a Swastika carved into their forehead. Aldo did that to the guy he let go in that scene, and he told him, that you need to tell them that we let you go so you can spread fear about us, and not because you gave us information so you won't get shot. Also when somebody dies for their country and refuses to help them Sgt. Donnie Donowitz (Eli Roth) also know as "The Bear Jew" kills that person by beating them to death with a bat. That is the introduction to The Basterds, and what the concept of what they do is. That part of the story is the violent side that sets up the suspense for how later on they will get their revenge on the Nazi's and end the war.

In the opening scene Col. Hans (Christoph waltz) also known as "The Jew Hunter" massacres a Jewish family hiding below Perrier LaPadite's (Denis Menochet) house, but one girl named Shosanna (Mélanie Laurent) gets away. She later goes on to own a movie theater, and that is the 2nd part of the story. That part also helps set up the suspense, and it really helps add a different background to the story. This film brings these two different story lines, and tells them in chronological order, and as the film goes on they are brought together beautifully.

The film gave an amazing perspective on slavery, and I loved every minute. It was just another film that made me grateful to be a movie buff, and to be a Tarantino fan. He is my favorite director, and I will always look to his work for inspiration when I try to pursue my dream of being a film director. The only thing with this film is that all the different languages, and the fact that you have to read it makes it hard to follow after a while. That is why I liked it so much more the 2nd time. Other then that part of the film it was so epic, and it was beautifully done. It gave a different perspective on a really controversial topic, and it gave that perspective beautifully.

However that perspective may upset people, because some people may be mad that he didn't tell the holocaust they way it was. He told it the way he wish it really happened instead of how it really happened. Some may think that he should not have done that, but I agree with what he did, because it was an interesting idea that he did. A film where Jews are killing Nazi's during the holocaust and getting their revenge on them has not been done before, and I feel like it was a good thing to do. I could never criticize Quentin Tarantino for what he does, because it takes courage to tackle topics like this, weather you are giving a new perspective on it, or of you are telling it the way it really was. This is an amazing movie, and I really hope that most people agree with the way I feel about what I think that Tarantino was trying to do with it.

Narrowly escaping with her life, she plots her revenge several years later when German war hero Fredrick Zoller takes a rapid interest in her and arranges an illustrious movie premiere at the theater she now runs. With the promise of every major Nazi officer in attendance, the event catches the attention of the "Basterds", a group of Jewish-American guerilla soldiers led by the ruthless Lt. Aldo Raine. As the relentless executioners advance and the conspiring young girl's plans are set in motion, their paths will cross for a fateful evening that will shake the very annals of history.

Plot: Fairly concise,  but over the top in a Tarantino kind of way. It is constantly changing setting and focus, but yet retains enough of a coherent plot to pull the whole movie together in the end. It's overall themes, as I see it, are that of revenge, finishing a job, and arrogance.

Acting/Script: The entire cast does a beautiful job of bringing their characters to life (especially Mr. Waltz) and the conversations are engaging enough to hold your attention completely even when not much is happening on screen. There are some especially hilarious moments to be had with many of Brad Pitt's lines. Zoller's character is also a gripping way to help relate the Nazi's back to the audience, as a way of reminding them there were individual people among their ranks, and they all weren't the same.

Soundtrack: Eclectic, but always fitting for their scenes. The music really does match what they are set to, and are used to really contrast several scenes' tones against each other.

Visuals: As this is a Tarantino movie, you can expect a lot of tabletop shots, shots done to imitate other movies' styles,  and an almost gratuitous amount of blood. Quentin Tarantino paints with a red brush, but does so with master strokes, making it seem more like art than unnecessary violence. 

Overall: I'd say go see it, but your probably already have. It is an interesting piece of historical-fiction, and keeps you entertained and gripped throughout. The best way to describe it is as a comic book version of a WW2 historical fiction brought to the big screen. 4.5/5

It is really known that when you see a movie by Quentin Tarantino, you are in for a movie experience like any other. The man who brought us Kill Bill, Django Unchained, and Pulp Fiction brings Inglorious Bastards. I expected really slick dialogue and a lot of action. Inglorious was his worst movie since Kill Bill 2.
Brad Pitt stars, I guess he stars since he is in the movie so little, as a leader of the Inglorious Bastards. The Bastards hunt down and kill Nazis. When Pitt is on screen he is entertaining and he did a good job acting, but I wanted to see him more. It takes a long time to introduce his character and we don't see him all that much. Instead, the movie focuses on many characters and it is almost confusing to remember who is who. There was also the Jewish girl who escapes, the members of the inglorious bastards, a few key Nazis including Hitler, the random lady who I don't even know the name of, and then there is the Nazi General played by Christoph Waltz.
Waltz is the only reason I didn't hate the movie. He saved the movie for me. He won an Oscar for best actor in a supporting role and for most of the movie I was trying to figure out why. He shows up a lot in the beginning speaking back and forth from English, French, and German, but his conversations are just boring. Pulp Fiction had conversations about milkshakes and it was way more interesting than any conversation in Inglorious Bastards. By the end his characters actions and a really intense scene between Waltz and Pitt really sucked me in and did save the movie for me. I was waiting for something to happen and there were flashes of brilliance in the movie but overall it was disappointing.
The strongest point to a Tarantino movie is the dialogue along with some intense action scenes. This movie had very few of both. The very first scene of a movie is very important. Star Wars had Darth Vader's introduction. Lord of the Rings had the seven minute prologue. Pulp Fiction had the incredible conversation in the diner. This movie had nothing. I was uninterested from the very beginning. It is Waltz and a French farmer talking about nonsense and after almost ten minutes of pointless talk it gets interesting. The Frenchman was hiding Jews under the floorboards and the last minute or two of the opening scene had such a little impact because of the boring conversation. It didn't work for me.
A lot of people didn't like that most of the movie wasn't in English and that it was subtitled. Now, I love subtitles. Even when a movie is 100%in English I put on subtitles. It is just a habit so subtitles didn't bother me. However, the subtitles took me out of the experience and I'm not too sure why. It made it difficult for me to connect or care with any of the characters. I got a few characters confused and a lot of them were just unimportant. There was a long scene in a bar and again, it had a good ending to the scene but the events leading up to it dragged on and on.
This movie isn't suppose to be historically accurate, but this makes zero sense. The basic idea of the movie is to get a large group of Nazi leaders in a movie theatre to present a German war movie, and kill them all. It is the act of a Jew to get revenge on the Nazis with the help of Brad Pitt and the bastards. First off, Nazi leaders would never put all of their leaders in the same room, or at least they would premier in Germany and not France. Trying to sell this idea is completely crazy and you know this would never ever be possible. The ending scenes were amusing and fun to watch, as unrealistic as they were I still laughed. The final scene of the movie was terrible because I was asking myself "That's it? What happens next? That was dumb." The story wasn't finished. I feel like it was laziness by Tarantino which was unexpected.
Was this movie a disaster? No, when there were action scenes they were really awesome. A huge Jew beats the skull in of a German officer and how do you not enjoy the sight of a Nazi getting demolished by a Jew? Pitt had a lot of smart dialogue and I loved his accent. The confrontation between him and Waltz was great, but it could have been so much better. This entire movie can really be summed up in a word, disappointment.
Overall, Inglorious Bastards was not Tarantino's best, but it was not his worst either. I remember seeing trailers for this movie and I thought it looked stupid and I was uninterested. I then learned who Tarantino was and saw his movie and I needed to see this movie. I saw this movie because of its director but I didn't feel like I was watching one of his movies. I didn't know what I was watching but out of respect for the director I finished the movie and salvaged what I could. I did my best to enjoy this movie but it gets the WillyT A for Effort.

This movie is tense. If you don't like tense films, do not watch this film. Also, if you don't want to "read your movies" (watch a movie with subtitles), don't watch this film. Tarantino's realistic language is actually really cool. I don't see films use language as much as this film does. So yeah, the language is a huge part of this movie, but as far as tensity goes, good God. Like, seriously, every scene creates at atmosphere of building suspense as you wonder "what they Hell is going to happen?!", and it works oh so well. Really, the film is full of a bunch of these tense scenes, and just combines them all, and I mean that in a really good way. Yes, there are some "fun" scenes to be found here, but they are few and far between. The dialogue is so extremely important in an amazing project by Quentin Tarantino. As for the acting, one cannot talk about this film without talking about two people, Brad Pitt, who is really good here, and Christoph Waltz, playing a cold-hearted bastard (no pun intended, I swear to God) of a character, who you loathe, but cannot be anything less than astounded by, because his motives are so interesting, going beyond just a Nazi who hates the Jews because he is a Nazi. Also, this film carries the distinct honor of having a spectacular final 30-45 minutes. There are about two or three plots going on in this film, and all of them are well established and interesting, and they all connect by the end, and it is just a fantastic screenplay by Tarantino, whose screenplays are always revered, and with very good reason. Overall, this is one of Tarantino's best, and definitely stands out as his most dense film to date, taking a vastly more serious approach (not to say that Tarantino is never serious, but just that this film is far more so than any other in my opinion), and is a must-watch for any Tarantino fan, though they likely already have.

This movie basically boils down to four one-act plays plus a short film that ties them all together, and some of these stories are more successful than others.

Michael Fassbender's brief but impactful appearance as an undercover British agent is a highlight, and what transpires in the basement bar is one of the most suspenseful scenes I've seen in some time. The tale of Melanie Laurent's Shoshanna is also rather moving, even if I'm not exactly sure what Tarantino has to say about her (Or really, any of the other characters) in the end. 

This is a strange and often confused film, but it's expertly crafted and probably a lot more fun than it oughta be.

Inglourious Basterds follows Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) and his group of 'basterds' as they invade Nazi-occupied France with the mission to claim Nazi scalps. The basterds team up with German actress Bridget von Hammersmark (Diane Kruger) when they learn that the Nazis will be attending the French premiere of "The Nation's Pride," a German propaganda film based on the heroic tale of Fredrick Zoller (Daniel Brühl). The Basterds hatch an explosive plan to use the premiere to wipe out as many Nazis as they possibly can; yet with diabolical Col. Hans 'Jew Hunter' Landa (Christoph Waltz) on their case, would the plan go off as expected. (no pun intended).

Tarantino yet again does a film the way he wants to, and with Inglourious Basterds he writes his own history. As expected, the script and dialogue is phenomenal, heavy, but extraordinarily good. The characters he writes are incredible to watch on screen, and he yet again casts beautifully. However, what stops Basterds from being up their will Pulp Fiction is that the segments that the film is split into, doesn't quite fit together as sweetly as Pulp Fiction did. This film feels more like a bunch of sequences just placed together rather than one individual film, whereas with Pulp, although split into different stories, the sequences fit together so nicely that it worked brilliantly.

As with all Quentin Tarantino, the actors chosen are sublime with the stand-out performance going to Christoph Waltz. Waltz's Hans Landa takes evil to a new level as he interrogates his victim with such confidence, such calmness, that he provokes fear from his reputation and ruthlessness. Landa's personality oozes charm with a straight shooting malice (in four language) that is just outstanding to watch. Hugely deserving of the Oscar for best supporting actor and the making of this film.

For any die-hard QT fan this film will not disappoint. Will it polarize the audience? Possibly.
