Inglourious Basterds - As a multi-equilibrium and frequently non-linear piece, complete with an array of influences and film references within itself, Inglourius Basterds is a welcome addition to the Tarantino collection.

In a visionary re-imagining of World War II history, the film takes place in Nazi-occupied France, where a group of American undercover soldiers called the "Basterds" hunt out Nazis and kill them as brutally as they can, sending the Nazi leaders a message about the Jewish resistance and about their impending doom. These soldiers are led by LT. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt). While they go about their mission, the Nazis have appointed a merciless, cold-minded and calculating detective, Col. Hans Landa (Christoph Waltz) to hunt down Jews hidden across France. Shosanna (Mélanie Laurent) narrowly avoided being killed by him as he massacred her entire family, and a few years later she got a new identity as a movie theater owner. She meets a handsome war hero (Daniel Bruhl), who's also a Nazi, and the Germans made an important movie about his battle feats; he is attracted by Shosanna and wants to move the premier of his film over to her theater, which makes Col. Hans Landa get involved in security issues with the theater and which makes the Basterds start concocting a plan on how to bust the Nazi-populated event.

"Inglourious Basterds" may well be regarded as Tarantino's most brutal film, with detailed scenes of scalping, carving, clubbing etc. (though I personally still regard "Reservoir Dogs" as his most violent work). "Basterds" is a brutal film, at times, but personally, I also regard "Inglourious Basterds" as his funniest film. I almost died laughing at some points in the film - which includes a wide range of Tarantinoesque humor, some of it actually very subtle. A scene in which Aldo Raine claims to be Italian is just one example of many incredibly hilarious moments. I was amazed that primary Nazi villains such as Hitler and Goebbles were shown with a quite human side rather than one-dimensional monsters - which, of course makes them even more monstrous in any thinking person's mind. Hitler himself seems like a babbling and pathetic idiot. No doubt that some people will find this offensive. 

I'm not sure if this is Tarantino's masterpiece as he himself claims to be, but it's surely his most meaningful work. The story presents us with an alternate WWII setting in which the war is fought by way of movies that established national identity. The main villain of the film, and also the best character QT has ever written, is Hans Landa, a.k.a. the Jew Hunter. Almost at the end of the film we find out that he's a double-crosser, and I think that's the element that sets him on a lower moral scale than the other characters. He's not proud of his lineage or country - he's a professional detective and merciless killer who fights only for himself.

Other levels of meaning relate to the way in which language works, either to communicate or to break communication. In the opening scene, which borrows shots literally from Lee Van Cleef's introduction in "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly", the Jew Hunter challenges our perception of language in Hollywood movies by specifically shifting gears halfway through the conversation in order to get to his objective. Later on, the culture clash and the ignorance of other people's languages become deadly important for our undercover heroes. QT seems to argue that it's that very same cultural racism (for lack of a better expression) that causes the atrocities of war in the very first place.

For a film so colorfully ostentatious, Basterds is a film imbued with great amounts of depth and subtlety. Essentially, this is a film about the audience. We see Hitler laugh hysterically at the Americans being slaughtered in the film-within-a-film Nation's Pride, and our natural instinct is repulsion - but it quickly dawns upon us that laughing at nasty, painful death is exactly how we've spent the last two hours. Having the twentieth century's ultimate figure of evil indulging in the same edgy delights as our good selves might send a ripple of unease over an audience which laughed heartily at the Bear Jew (a surprisingly accomplished Eli Roth) clobber a Nazi soldier to death whilst yelling baseball conventions. Just like Roth's own Hostel, we find ourselves forced to question why we find the violence so entertaining.

The movie is rich in characters, and boy are there a lot of them with quite a bit of screen time. Brad Pitt is definitely the main character of the Americans, and he gives an over the top, often times comedic performance. Diane Kruger plays a rather minor, but interesting role as a German movie star who is actually a spy for the Americans. Every role played is played well, but unlike as it would seem by the trailers, all these actors aren't wrapped around Brad Pitt's finger, but instead Christoph Waltz's. 

Tarantino provides us with an absolutely menacing presence with Hans Landa, a German colonel who appears in the opening scenes in a manner akin to Angel Eyes in "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" (this is surely intentional, of course), only his evil is the smiling, chilling kind that reminds one of a William S. Buroughs line: the face of evil is the face of total need. Landa needs information, constantly, and asks so questioningly and with such cunning that we feel a sense of uncommon dread when he appears on screen, even when its just to eat a pastry with the (incognito) Shosanna. Take your eyes off this guy, I dare you. He's about as hypnotic and alluring and subtle as they come, and can floor you like Samuel L. Jackson reciting a Bible quote.

The film is magnificently shot and the settings are perfect. Apart from a magnificent intuition for general European and American cultural details, Tarantino once again pays tribute to countless cinematic idols. The film, which owes its title to Enzo Castellari's WW2-Exploitation classic "Quel Maldetto Treno Blindato" ("Inglorious Bastards", 1978) was originally said to be a sort of remake of Robert Aldrich's "The Dirty Dozen" (1967). It is not a remake of either film, but it alludes to both of them, Castellari even has a cameo as a Nazi. Apart from obvious referrals to German pre-war cinema, many cinema figures are alluded to. As a huge fan of Italian Horror films, I was delighted to hear Eli Roth use the pseudonym "Antonio Margheriti" (Like Antonio Margheriti, the magnificent Italian director of films such as "Castle of Blood", "The Virging of Nuremberg" and "And God Said To Cain"). The most obvious tribute for cult-cinema fans is the film's score: Tarantino re-uses large parts of Ennio Morricone's soundtrack to Sergio Sollima's brilliant Spaghetti Western "La Resa Dei Conti" ("The Big Gundown", 1966). 

The phrase 'kosher porn' has been tossed around by some reviewers to describe the visceral, vengeful joy the film provides. These certainly aren't the Jewish characters you tend to see in more conventional war films. Their gleeful, effervescently comic brutality makes the Nazis the victims, inverting preconceptions of the place of Jewish figures in war films by making them figures of absolute power rather than desperate resisters. It's actually their Nazi victims that seem to elicit glimmers of sympathy rather than our heroes. We're given very little background on the Basterds themselves, whilst their scalped, carved and shot targets talk of defending their people, hugging their mothers and seeing their children grow up.

My two major quibble with the film is it's set-up. The way the movie is set up, it's only loosely thrown together until everything at the end brings the stories together. So for the first hour and a half (or around there), this movie felt like a constantly changing anthology. Once chapter five binds it together and gives us a typical great Tarantino ending, it makes the movie whole. But the looseness of the film towards the middle brought up questions as to what the purpose of different characters were. Luckily, the answers are all in the last chapter.

The other detail that didn't ring true for me was the fact that the German movie star, Zoller, suddenly became an asshole right before getting killed. For me, even in a movie that admits its manipulative techniques, that went over the line. Instead of showing a character which had been portrayed as kind and well-behaved getting randomly killed for getting in the way of vengeance, I suspect QT felt the need to suddenly darken the character so we wouldn't hold his death against the movie and I thought that was a cheap shot. Regardless, Shohana and Zoller's truncated love story is the emotional center of this epic film.

The rest of the film sets up what will happen with typical rich Tarantino dialogue, and some bloody violence. Definitely it's a unique take on World War II.

Inglorious Bastards is Quentin Tarantino's spectacular return to form following 2007's major disappointment Death Proof. Inglorious Basterds is a bizarrely original take on World War II and blends horrific violence and comic relief perfectly. This is withouth a doubt my favourite Tarantino film other than Pulp Fiction. It has everything wanted and expected of a Tarantino film with a great script, magnificent performances and memorable characters.

Brad Pitt stars as Lt. Aldo Raine who leads a team of killers known as the Bastards into Nazi-occupied France to kill every Nazi that crosses their path. He gives an enjoyable and comic performance and is by far one of Tarantino's most likeable characters to date. Christoph Waltz steals the show as Col. Hans (The Jew Hunter). Hans is my favourite of all of Tarantino's created characters and nobody could of portrayed this character over than Waltz. Christoph Waltz's dialogue is superbly wrote and his performance is nothing short of spectacular.

The supporting cast is strong with good performances from Mélanie Laurent, Diane Kruger, Eli Roth, Michael Fassbender and Til Schweiger. Also there's a great cameo from Mike Myers. The different stories within the film cross over brilliantly and the climax is thoroughly enjoyable.

Inglorious Bastards celebrates and incorporates everything that is great about Quentin Tarantino's film making. The cast is perfectly assembled and the diversity of big Hollywood names and unknowns is well balanced. The script for me is Tarantino's best piece to date, its twisted, chilling and surprisingly comical also. The violence is glorified and controversially questionable as expected, but entertaining and of an acquired taste.

Auteurism is a term coined for directors like Tarantino. His movies are quickly recognisable for many reason; dialogue (a lot of it), soundtrack, references to movies from yester-year, clever juxtapositions of styles and super-cool-ness. Inglorios Basterds is no different.

I find the soundtrack and music to the film magnificent. For a man who has spaghetti westerns running through his veins, the music of Morricone is instantly recognisable. In my mind he is the greatest composer for movie soundtracks to walk the face of the Earth - period. When the music pumps out over certain scenes it makes me tingle. Due to the tone he has used it makes a lot of the film seem like a western to me. Just with soldiers instead of cowboys. COME ON GUYS, work with me here! Both wear funny hats, boots and carry guns ... no?
Like Kill Bill's East meets West feel, Basterds has an America meets France feel to it. Obviously its in the story, but the shots and music cleverly intertwining to create something new. A totally "Franerican" feel to it. While we're on the subject of soundtracks, the use of certain specific tracks taken from other movies like Kelly's Heroes and Zulu Dawn, at the moments they were used, adds an extra dimension. The David Bowie song Cat People (putting out the fire) is unexpected and another interesting, intriguing, absorbing and enthralling moment. 
Moving past the music, I found the movie really fun. It moves from very dark to very light hearted quite quickly. I am not the biggest Brad Pitt fan in the world but I must admit I loved him in this movie. Especially his attempted Italian, sorry EYE-talian. I am however, a big Fassbender fan (wowee!) and was entertained by him in this movie, as with everything he's done. 

I wanted to mention (whilst language is on the table) that I made some heavy and judgemental comments about The Boy in Striped Pyjamas' usage of The Queens English. This movie highlights my point all the way through. The importance of accent and language, whether laughing at EYE-talian or asking to move to the English language for the remainder of the conversation. It's funny and interesting in Inglourious Basterds for the same reason its wrong in Striped Pajamas. For authenticity, for the script to work, for the audience to "buy-into" the movie and for credibility you must get it right - otherwise it's a joke. 

In short, Inglourious Basterds is a mass of contrasting styles; American's - in France, Nazi's - killing Nazi's, war movie - Western soundtrack, scalping - in '40's France, fact and fiction. It's entertaining, different, fun and although it's not up there with the best war movies or even the best Tarantino movies it definitely doesn't disappoint. I enjoyed it a lot.

It was more like 2.5 hours of Tarantino indulging his inner movie-geek by putting all his favorite elements of film into one. And there is nothing wrong with that because his combination of beautiful violence, complex dialogue and black humor make for a great film, but it definitely wasn't his greatest.

The stand out for me was Melanie Laurent, who played Shoshanna. She had all the qualities of Tarantino's leading ladies- she was uniquely beautiful and equally as feisty. The final scenes with her (I don't want to ruin it for anyone) were pure film gold. Brad Pitt was also fantastic as Aldo Raine as was Eli Roth as Donny, or the 'Bear Jew'.

Tarantino does violence and death scenes with such absolute beauty; the gore is underplayed because the use of slow motion, epic music and stunning bloodwork is captivating. I did find some of his talking heads scenes to be a little drawn out- I know Tarantino writes wonderfully intelligent dialogue but some of the tangents seemed like he was trying to prove just how much he knows about film, rather than being integral to the scene.

I also found Diane Kruger a bit of a let down. Her character Bridget von Hammersmark was great, but I don't think Kruger took ownership of the role. She didn't have the confidence or charisma of any of Tarantino's other main ladies.

Overall a great cinematic experience, but perhaps not as supreme as it has been talked up to be. I actually think reviewers are scared they will lose credibility if they don't rate a Tarantino film- but seeing as I have none, what have I got to lose?

The plot is straightforward, the characters are one dimensional, though Waltz' character had some depth, and the world is simply good versus evil.  How in the world does he pull it off?  

The genius of Tarantino is his dialogue and the small twists he throws into his scenes.  His mastery of language and dialogue is ridiculous.  The humor and thoughtfulness that goes into it is always fresh.  His scenes are built to capture your attention and not let go of you until he reveals the ending.  You think you know what is going to happen, and you will be partially correct, but his twists each time surprise you.  

Tarantino weaves and fuses different genres, from westerns, noir, war movies, exploitation films in such a way that baffle the viewer. Tarantino does what any amateur film lover wish he could do.  He provides original material wrapped up inside gems of the past creating a huge puzzle for the film lover to piece together and entertainment for the rest.  His mastery of the genres and film making camera shots know how to create truly "moving pictures."

The movie will not be appreciated by WWII purists and those who detest gore. If you can watch it for the film experience, you need to watch it.

What is fascinating, which I have not seen discussed, is that Tarantino recognizes Hitler's love of moving pictures.  Hitler even considered going to a fine arts type college, but was not accepted.  Hitler would never attend a public screening, but would watch movies on his own.  Charlie Chaplin was one of his favorite film makers.

I want to simply give this movie four stars for being a well told narrative with not much depth, but a small voice tells me I need to watch it again and I have a feeling it will make me appreciate it even more.  It is definitely a film I need to watch again.

Quentin Tarantino, quite possibly the best film style re-interpreter based in America, as well as the author of some of the most distinctly human characters in recent history, crafts what is simultaneously a spectacular Jewish revenge fantasy and an emphatic statement of opposition to the most heinous film producers/studio (The Third Reich) in the history of the art.

The plot is pretty black and white, presenting a low-guilt historical fantasy in a beautiful way.  What might be even more distinctive though is Tarantino's portrayal of the Third Reich as, among other things, the most horrible film studio and era in the history of film.  Not only is this film's conclusion a fantastic alternate ending for one of history's worst wars, it's also a passionate vanquishing of a suffocated era of German and French cinema.  It serves to liberate both the Jews and the filmmakers from the atrocious norm that had developed.  Like in most totalitarian societies, the artistry was greatly reduced and concentrated into a few key pieces, Riefenstahl's films in the case of Nazi Germany.  Also, pairing the story of Shosanna, a female Jewish survivor and the namesake Basterds of the film gave the story more tension and dynamism than it would have sported had the story just been about one of them.

The other thing about this film that demands mention (besides Christoph Waltz) is the style and beautiful visuals.  Tarantino inserts very entertaining mini-documentaries, title freezes, and ultra-dramatic music into the overall narrative, making the grindhouse and spaghetti western influences front and center at times.  The cinematography, costumes, and production design are all quite premium.  Even though the story and dialog is front and center with this film, it is undoubtedly one of the most visually sexy Tarantino films yet released.  

Well, anything else I'd say in a review at this point would do you less service than seeing the actual film, so please do.  You'll be treating yourself to a highly stylish and entertainingly iconic film.  (31 December 2012)

Another masterpiece from Quentin Tarantino! Tarantino's alternate history/fictional story surrounding World War II and Nazi occupied France is a dramatic, sometimes funny, often clever and always entertaining war film.

The film had various different sub plots that all tied up quite nicely to the film's main story surrounding a Nazi film premiere that will be attended by Fuhrer himself and high rankers. A plot to get rid of the Nazi's by American soldiers known as the "Basterds" lead by Lt. Aldo Raine in an amazing performance by Brad Pitt, playing the role of the Southern soldier, complete with mannerisms and accent to perfection, Pitt's character as well served at times as "black comic" relief. 

Tarantino again brilliantly devises his "chapter" technique in this film, dividing up small story arcs leading up to one awesomely executed climax, the end of the war in the burning theatre room orchestrated by a vengeful surviving Jewish woman from the film's opening massacre.  The woman, Shosanna played emotionally by Melanie Laurent was a perfect casting. 

The film had a greatly assembled cast from small roles played by Michael Fassbender and Mike Myers. However the film's standout performance no doubt goes to Christoph Waltz as the classy, but deviant and dangerous SS Colonel Hans Landa. He was evil, remorseless and upon film's end a traitor to the country he served for years. Waltz's performance was so great it garnered him an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, no doubt, he is truly deserving of this. 

I praise the film's costume design and set decoration making the film feel very authentic and as accurate to 1940's Nazi occupied France as possible. 

Tarantino creates yet another unique film that in the years to come will be regarded as among some of the best war films.

If I had to pick a single film to demonstrate the raw power of the entertainment industry and filmmaking itself, then Inglorious Basterds would most definitely be my first choice. I've heard a lot of people complain that Basterds is "historically inaccurate", "offensive", and even call the film out as "Jewish propaganda". This film, like any great film, has a lot of its substance up for interpretation, as an impressionist may have with a painting of his that is considered a masterpiece. It's a very sad matter that many people nowadays take things in film too seriously, and don't bother to scope out a film's true subject matter. This is the case for Inglourious Basterds - I feel that many people don't "get" the film in a certain context. However, it is one of my favorite movies of all time, and I'll tell you why. 

Right off the bat while watching this film you'll notice something isn't particularly "normal" about this film - real-life figures are caricatured into cartoonish versions of themselves, waltzing around .....

Immensely entertaining, finding the right balance of drama and comedy, this is one of Tarantino's most ambitious films in years, and thanks to great performances from Christoph Waltz and Melanie Laurent, it works as an alternative history film with plenty of satire to boot.

One of the problems with Quentin Tarantino's Inglorious Basterds becomes evident within the long and brilliant opening sequence.  Col. Hans Landa arrives at a French farmhouse looking for Jews.  He engages the owner in a long conversation in French, but then asks to speak to the proprietor in English, in order to better practice that language.  The switch has a narrative purpose, since Landa wants to threaten the owner in a language that the hidden Jews are unable to understand, but the film is also winking at the audience, making fun of the American disdain for subtitles by saying plainly, "yeah, I could have done this scene in English the whole time."  

       The opening scene is not only one of the best in the movie, but one of the best Tarantino has ever shot as well, but as the movie continues, the constant winking at "this is only a movie, let's have fun" and the truly horrific real life events that the film is depicting an alternative to, becomes more and more disturbing.  The opening sequence begins the story of Shoshanna Dreyfus (Melanie Laurent), the one escapee of this horrible massacre, who spends the next few years obsessed with revenge.  While Tarantino made a revenge movie successfully with Kill Bill, that film actually had moral complexity, despite existing in the cartoonish world of Kung Fu and Samurai movies.  Shoshanna remains fairly one-dimensional, and though her revenge may be just as deserved and more horrific than that of the Bride, there is no moral reflection on her part.  She never seems to question what she is doing even for a moment.  

       Due to the cutting back and forth between Shoshanna and The Basterds themselves, a group of Jewish American soldiers out to kill Hitler, the movie has less narrative thrust then Kill Bill and meanders.  The depiction of the  Basterds is equally morally simplistic.  Led by Aldo Raines (Brad Pitt), a southern fried gentile tough guy caricature, the group brutally tortures and maims Nazi soldiers, in a way that makes us question why we should regard them as any better than the Nazis themselves.  The fact that the existence of this group in this movie whitewashes American anti-Semitism to make it seem as if our country was pro-Jewish, and ignores the fact that the horrors of the Holocaust, that these Jewish soldiers are presumably avenging, were unknown to American soldiers at the time, makes the rewriting of history offensive.  

      Tarantino shows none of the moral complexity of some of the films that inspired this one.  In Sam Fuller's The Big Red One, we are given a gritty and ironic look at war that shows how it dehumanizes us, but at the same time seems like a rollicking adventure film.  In The Dirty Dozen, the soldiers are convicts sent on a suicide mission to earn their freedom.  They do not want to fight but must.  Their mission is similar to the Basterds, but they are simply a merry band of sadists, and Tarantino does not have a single character among them that stands out.  

        The movie does have its pleasures.  There is a long sequence in the middle of the film involving a movie star working as a spy that matches the opening sequence for brilliance.  There is also the great Oscar winning performance from Christoph Waltz as Landa, the movies chief villain.  Waltz is so good in the movie that he makes the reprehensible villain impossible not to love and even when the ironic ending arrives and he gets what he deserves, this underscores the cruelty of the vision Tarantino has created.  

           Perhaps the most controversial element in the movie is the way that it rewrites history to give World War 2 a feel good ending.  This is ballsy work by Tarantino, but what is the point?  Showing Jews blowing Hitler away may be fun revenge fantasy, but it only makes it more depressing the realities of the Holocaust.    We know this did not happen and there is nothing clever about it.  It comes off as lazy and puerile.  Aldo Raines tells us at the end "this just might be my masterpiece," but Mr. Tarantino needs to keep looking for a film to match Pulp Fiction in his distinctive oeuvre.
